{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/eyes-in-the-sky-to-tackle-traffic/article_f69eaa53-01ea-5efb-bbda-ac5b5256e928.html", "TITLE": " Eyes in the sky to tackle traffic ", "DATE": "May 22, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " EYES in the sky will take the place of police officers on the nation's highways to monitor errant motorists. The first phase of the National Transport Management System (NTMS) will focus on the East-West Corridor, and is geared at reducing traffic congestion. Canadian company IBI Group, which specialises in Intelligent Transportation Systems, was awarded a $42 million three-year contract, by the National Infrastructural Development Company (Nidco) to organise and implement the programme, on behalf of the Ministry of Works and Transport. The NTMS is an Intelligent Transportation System (ITS) that comprises the Corridor Traffic Management System (CTMS), Traffic Surveillance and Control Systems (TSCS), and the National Traffic Management Centre (NTMC). ITS is the application of advanced and emerging technology in transportation to save time, money, energy and the environment using computers, sensors, information systems, software, communications and electronic devices. The system's aims, in this first phase, are to mitigate the traffic congestion along the East-West Corridor. According to Navin Ramsingh, the programme's project manager, this area has the highest traffic density and congestion in the country, with over 3,000 cars travelling along it daily. Ministry permanent secretary Cheryl Blackman said that the programme was Information Technology-driven and geared towards improving traffic flow, as well as help law enforcement better monitor roads. NIDCO president, Dr Carson Charles, said the aim was to ensure the travelling public is given the level of service and technology it deserves. Benefits of the system include improved travel times; increased travel speeds on the highway during peak times; and quicker response by emergency and law enforcement during crises. The improved flow of traffic will also mean less police time dedicated to traffic management, and diverted to other more pressing duties. The NTMS will also aid in planning for emergencies and evacuations of Port-of-Spain in the event of any type of disasters. The NTMC is the central monitoring room for the system. Located on the second floor of the Ministry's headquarters and designed by IBI Group, it is a state-of-the-art space that can remotely control the various technologies utilised by the system. It is fitted with six screens that simultaneously monitor different areas along the corridor in real time. The CTMS involves 10 CCTV (closed-circuit television) cameras with pan/tilt/zoom features for a 360-degree view of the corridor. It also has 16 vehicle detection stations to monitor the average speed of traffic. There will also be two Variable Message Signs (already installed on the Churchill-Roosevelt Highway ) to provide updates from the Ministry about traffic conditions or accidents so commuters can decide if they need to take alternative routes. The TSCS will monitor traffic lights and signals. It can be controlled remotely by the NTMC, who can modify them according to the flow and density of traffic. Works and Transport Minister Jack Warner said that he would soon be taking a note to Cabinet to approve the formation of a National Incident Management Team comprising law enforcement, emergency response personnel and traffic personnel. They will meet monthly to discuss how best to improve and shorten response time. This is part of the Ministry's plan to create three incident management programmes: The Motorist Assistance Programme; Rapid Freeway Clearance Programme; and Mobility Response Team. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/rising-from-ashes-of-blackout-trauma/article_234f043c-edbb-57e2-89ed-f22b03c84cdb.html", "TITLE": " Rising from ashes of blackout trauma ", "DATE": "Mar 29, 2013 ", "CONTENT": " The lights have come back on, but Trinidad and Tobago has remained in the dark about the cause of that scary nationwide loss of electrical power from just after midnight, until Friday afternoon. Absent any evident natural disaster or plant accident, or incident, something like a worst-case scenario inexplicably took effect. Power-hungry households, businesses, industries, utilities, and sundry facilities were starved of vital electricity supply. The impact of a total blackout in the wee hours of the morning was such as to propel Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar out of bed to assume the position of personally observing the response of operatives at the Penal PowerGen plant. She later ordered a full report on just what had gone wrong and why, and how a recurrence can be prevented. An Energy Ministry release pointed to an expected meeting of all the major entities involved in providing power to the nation... to troubleshoot what had taken place. In the known story so far, some indeterminate something went wrong at the Point Lisas facility of Phoenix Park Gas Processors, an entity 51 per cent owned by State enterprise NGC. The effect was somehow to stop the flow of cleaned-up natural gas to power generators and to downstream industrial operations. But a double, or triple, whammy was to come: NGCs back-up, gas-enabling, redundancies just failed to respond in their hour of need. Moreover, the new power plant, installed by NGC, on Tobagos Cove Estate, also stumbled and fell down. If and how the Cove mishap in eastern Tobago was connected with the unpredictable fiascoes at Phoenix Park and at NGC on Trinidads west coast has yet to be clarified. What stands revealed, however, is the demonstrated reality that, in its all-important natural gas production, supply and utilisation industry, all of the republic of Trinidad and Tobago had suddenly been reduced to the rule of Murphys Law. Thus, everything that could go wrong on Friday morning apparently did go wrong. That turn of events, witnessed worldwide, flies in the face of T&Ts self-image as an accomplished player on the energy field. On that basis, this country has been offering expert services to emerging natural gas-producing countries in Africa. A single episode, even one as extreme as Fridays, should not disrupt long-settled recognition of where T&T stands in the world of energy. Energy Minister Kevin Ramnarine last year hailed Phoenix Parks distinguished safety record, which he described as a key element in attracting external investors to the company. Phoenix Park and NGC will likely rise from the ashes of world reputation likely incurred on Friday. But the trauma of countrywide power outage, at least until causes are known,will likely have a wide-ranging and lingering impact in T&T which endured it. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/we-are-living-in-a-state-of-denial/article_3f8ea24c-e6d2-536d-b362-2c53ba25cf23.html", "TITLE": " We are living in a state of denial ", "DATE": "Jun 14, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "TERROR THREAT: Terrence Deyalsingh TERROR THREAT: Terrence Deyalsingh The issues we face in T&T are phenomenal. Everyone seems to be quite aware of this, with the distinct exception of the sorry pack of individuals who call themselves politicians. These issues need not be elucidated upon here, in the interest of space; perhaps why they continue is of more interest. Upon close examination we recognise that the people with the visions of grandeur have one common policy, namely they continue to live in denial. By being in constant denial, they continue to insult citizens' intelligence, attributing every issue to opposition politics. We can begin with fireproof Martin Joseph who denies that we have a crime problem, despite numbers to the contrary. They use numbers to seek to baffle us; telling us how many \"patrols they conducted, how many tickets were issued, and how many exercises they undertook.'' Yet they never defined \"a patrol''. Is it that each time we see a police vehicle we can assume they are on patrol How does that explain when a victim in Pinto Road stopped a vehicle and told them he was robbed, they advised him to go to the Arima station while they continued on their merry way, with A/C blowing Or when they pass accidents and their victims on the nation's highways without the slightest effort to ascertain or assist FYI, Mr Joseph, people are not reporting many crimes today because we have no confidence in the police. Please don't take the lack of reports to believe that it is down. Check the murder rate and you will see. And then there's Health Minister Jerry Narace. Up to this day he has maintained that dengue is not a problem. So when he tells us that \"T&T is ready for the swine flu''. He and his gang are probably the only ones who believe this, if they actually do. Everyone with whom I have spoken expressed concerns to the contrary and rightly so. When we learn that people are sleeping on hospital floors for several nights before being placed in a room, it is a safe indicator that T&T is not ready for anything, least of all swine flu. Don't tell us how many vaccines there are at Mt Hopeless. Similarly, the good folks at Office of Disaster Preparedness Management, are another case in point. These goodly folks tell us that they are ready for any eventualities (LOL). Five minutes rain in Port of Spain and we know otherwise. Also, many of us were under the impression that the economy was really based on, among other things, oil prices. Energy Minister Conrad Enill had to put us in our place by telling us it was based on gas. So the drop in oil prices had no effect on the \"jillion'' dollar budget; consequently, there was no need to scale back on any of their mega projects--cost overruns and all. And the bills for the summit keeps coming in. And of course there's Karen Nunez-Tesheira, Minister of Finance, who I've noted is always pointing a finger, telling us that the global financial concerns are nothing to be really worried about. Of course if all our monies were protected a la Cyril Lawrence we would probably see things in a similar light. We might even roll over and be happy. Then there is President Max Richards who did no wrong. This list can go on to name all the others who live in denial. Thus when we see individuals violating laws of the land, whether it's driving on the PBR unauthorised, flying low on the shoulders of the highways, beating our women, leasing or renting firearms with the option to own, rest assured that they are only following the leader, as I believe Machel Montano said. And as long as they are in denial, they don't have to do anything. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/ground-zero-alarm-rises-in-maraval/article_bb6587a4-4868-54e5-9183-7c8777d4c577.html", "TITLE": " Ground zero alarm rises in Maraval ", "DATE": "Nov 26, 2010 ", "CONTENT": " Up a hill in Maraval, even when it's sunny and calm, an atmospheric disturbance is felt by residents, stirred into action by a premonition of disaster. Some 300 yards up Moraldo Street, a two-woman delegation of Donna Maria Diaz and Meena St Louis welcome a reporter and photographer to share a community sense of impending peril. The source of their alarm is a chenette tree, thrusting straight up some 60 or 70 feet from an embankment at the edge of St Louis' front yard. The tree rises over two neighbours' adjacent houses. \"The sweetest chenette in Trinidad come from this tree,\" said St Louis of the fruit it bore last July-August. But the tree is dying. It can fall at any time, and it's tall enough to worry not just occupants of the tall-pillared house in the yard, but also householders nearby. Such as Diaz, who lives across the narrow street in a smaller, low house, with her mother and her teenage daughter. \"A branch fall last month from quite on top,\" said St Louis, who has lived under it for 43 of her 65 years. \"In the night, you sleeping, and rain fall heavy, it scary. What about when it fall on me\" said Diaz. To an unclued eye, the tree looks neither shaky nor terminally ill. Rather than spreading, its branches cluster upward from the trunk, in a shape resembling a brush for shaving or dusting. But Diaz and St Louis point to the base of the trunk, where the wood looks rotted. Diaz reads the clipping of an October 12 Express report that a Laventille family of seven were left homeless after a mango tree crashed onto their house. \"If this tree fall on my little old house, who going to compensate me\" Residents want this trouble tree cut down. On October 19, thirty-six residents signed a letter requesting this, that went to TSTT, T&TEC, the Diego Martin Regional Corporation. The tree ismore than 100 years old, Diaz and St Louis believe. \"I born and meet that tree big,\" said Norma Diaz, mother of Donna. She was born 74 years ago,right on the spot now threatened by the tree. In her house, immediately next door to St Louis, the chenette tree also directly overhead, Myrtle O'Brien, 63,treats the fall of the tree with grim humour: \"I am not afraid the tree fall on meagain. It fall on me already. I feeling it.\" For Colm Imbert, area MP and former works minister, the tree is fresh in mind as a constituency cause going back \"more than ten years.\" He had tried to help. \"These efforts have always come up against an obstacle,\" he said, choosing his words carefully. All had once been set for a tree cutting and, for safety, T&TEC disconnected power. One resident, however, \"threatened violence on the ground that meat in her fridge was spoiling\". T&TEC reconnected and retreated. The chenette tree survived. Neighbourhood fears revive with every season of wind and rain, and every news story of a tree falling on houses. Is the tree, century-old source of sweetest chenette, really also a continuing danger to property and maybe life \"Yes,\" says botanist and columnist Julian Kenny who, at the request of the Express, inspected the Moraldo Street ground zero. \"It really ought to come down,\" he said, agreeing with the residents' 100-year age estimate. \"Having it there is asking for a serious accident.\" Prof Kenny diagnosed a fatal weakening from age, worsened by a giant Strangler Fig parasite whose thick roots are sucking life out of the chenette tree'strunk. Preventing a fallen-tree disaster from happening is harder than it seems. The problem literally stands inside the fenced front yard ofSt Louis, a widowed pensioner. \"The Forestry Division say they don't cut down trees on private property. I bring plenty people here to look at it.\" St Louis can't afford the cost, estimated as high as $10,000, of forestalling danger to private and public property. The chenette tree story is immediately familiar to Councillor Nadia Romany of the Diego Martin Regional Corporation, recalling a letter from a fearful neighbour. Her corporation is \"trying to form a tree-cutting team,\" she said. Meanwhile, should this tree qualify as an \"emergency,\" the corporation would refer it to the Office of Disaster Preparedness and Management. Until that determination, Councillor Romany said, removing a tree troubling to residents can be done only \"at a cost to burgessesto those who want it cut\". {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/china-is-china-japan-is-japan/article_db9120ed-0dd9-5855-b19a-0d94a5e6c0e4.html", "TITLE": " china is china... japan is Japan ", "DATE": "Mar 5, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "SIX-TIME CHAMP: Colin Ramasra Toshiyuki Kato, Parliamentary Vice-Minister for Foreign Affairs speaking to reporters in his Tokyo office. SIX-TIME CHAMP: Colin Ramasra Toshiyuki Kato, Parliamentary Vice-Minister for Foreign Affairs speaking to reporters in his Tokyo office. Toshiyuki Kato, Parliamentary Vice-Minister for Foreign Affairs was fairly blunt when I asked him about China's higher economic presence and its agressive and assertive role in the Caribbean when campared with Japan. What exactly was Japan's foreign policy interest in this region \"First of all I want to emphasise that there is no lack of interest on the part of Japan in the Caribbean region and in Caribbean countries. But the China Government way of providing support and aid in what form and what kinds of purpose or objective they have in mind for providing support, are very different from the Japanese Government. Because it is become very clear that the China Government would like to provide aid and support with two purposes in mind one to secure resources, especially natural resources for their population and China has a huge population of more than $1.3 billion. So in order to secure the future for that large population, they would need some kind of insurance and the resources are that insurance. \"The second purpose is to have a larger, stronger voice in the international community,\" Kato said. \"All over the world China is making gifts and presents to different countries in the form of monument-like buildings and structures. But in building such structures, tens of thousands of Chinese workers are being sent in. \"On the other hand Japan works in a different way. Japan in principle hires local people in order to be engage in such projects with a view to providing education and vocational training to upgrade the skills of the local people so technical skills and guidance are being given. At the end of the training the local people can have skills in manufacturing or production,\" he said. My Venezuelan colleague followed up on the question, but Kato maintained his stance, saying: \"We have no intention of competing with China. Of course there may be some situations where we would have to face China as a competitor but we don't intend to compete with China. China is China and Japan is Japan\". But he emphasised that Japan was on a major drive to reach out to the international community, whose support it so greatly appreciated, in the aftermath of the March 11, 2011, earthquake and tsunami disaster. \"We want to emphasise kizuna (a Japanese word meaning bond), not only (the bond) at the level of the family and community but at the international level...Because we received support from the rest of the world, the Government wanted to show the world that the survivors (of the disaster) can get back on the feet again. We are making a point to the international community that even if you face tragic experiences, if you work hard, you can get back on your feet again,\" Kato said as he sat down to speak to our group which consisted of ten journalists. Japan has all reason to open up to the international community as it seeks to recover not only from the earthquake/tsunami disaster of March 11, 2010 (which triggered a nuclear power station accident at the Fukushima plant) but also as it seeks to rebuild the economy amidst global financial market instability. Part of the mission of reconstruction is to prevent the spread of \"reputation damage\" and restore faith in the \"Japan brand\" by emphasising that its products are of a high quality and are safe trhough the dissemination of \"accurate information\". Japanese officials, were very sensitive to the fact that the nuclear fallout at Fukushima has produced international fear \"that everything made in Japan was contaminated\". \"We are trying to rectify such a wrong image. We have been using every opportunity to emphasise the point that things coming out of Japan are safe, and that there are stringent safety standards supported by international data\", Kato said. After 3/11 there were import restrictions on Japanese food products, especially those coming from the Tohoku (the region most affected by the nuclear fallout). Japan asked its trade partners to lift these restrictions but only Canada and Chile compiled with the request. But, it recognises that once import restrictions are introduced, it is an uphill battle to reverse this decision. Government officials stress that Japanese people are some of the most sensitive in terms of food safety issue and that all food distributed and circulated in the international market from Japan is safe. (Fishes are however not safe and the Government has placed a ban on all fishing.) We were taken to places where the \"rigorous testing\" of food and products is done. At Yokohama Port, we were shown how they measured, using a radioactive meter, all containers passing through that Port. \"Out of 150,000 containers measures at the Port, only 17 required decontamination, we were told. The Port is in the process of installing an automated testing system at a cost of one billion yen. Meanwhile radiation measurement on food grown in the disaster affected region is conducted at the Agricultural Safety Promotion Department of the Fukushima Agricultural Technology Centre. The Department which opened in June 2011, tests all beef cattle as well as raw materials such as feed from the Fukushama region. There was a ban on all beef from Fukushama but it was lifted in September 2011. Still the radiation fears due to \"negative rumours\" have led to a 40 per cent drop in the price of beef because of the lower demand, officials revealed. The Government has sought to compensate farmers, buying at a cost of (US$1 billion) all the beef which could not be shipped and it has also paid for feed (at a cost of US$1.6 billion). One of Japan's primary contacts with the world is the motor car industry. And most of the cars coming to the Caribbean and Latin America were shipped directly from Japan. We visited Toyota Corporation's Toyko office and Masami Doi, Project General Manager Public Affairs Division explained why shipments to the Caribbean and Latin America were interrupted during the 3/11 disaster. Toyota has three factories in the disaster affected region of Tohoku. \"Mr Toyota ordered us to stop the automobile production line immediately after the earthquake becasue it would have meant that the workers at Toyota would have had to report to work and would not have been able to help their familities and their citizens in the region who were suffering,\" Toyota suppled food, water, gasoline, using its large trucks to the people of the region. \"Mr Toyota said 'save and support the people in the region',\" Doi said. \"We regret the inconvenience caused to our Caribbean and Latin American consumers. But afterwards, we increased the production so that we could respond to their situation in a speedy manner in order to deliver vehicles and spare parts to our customers,\" he said. Toyota remains the most popular car in Japan. Ria Taitt visited Japan from January 27 to February 7 at the invitation of the Japanese Government. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/curb-road-carnage-with-punitive-laws/article_161b3897-9a76-5d71-bb8f-9b62578ac101.html", "TITLE": " Curb road carnage with punitive laws ", "DATE": "May 23, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "WOOING: A younger Sundar with Kayso. WOOING: A younger Sundar with Kayso. SOME 30-odd years ago, when the Solomon Hochoy Highway was completed and fully opened to traffic (initially, only one carriageway was built and used), accidents close to the Claxton Bay flyover were not uncommon. Many were fatal, and that at a time when there were fewer than one-third the vehicles we now have using the nation's roadways. Because accidents close to Claxton Bay happened more frequently than elsewhere, people tried to figure out why this was so. I should add that I have lived in Claxton Bay since 1973, so I know that section of the Hochoy Highway well. Superstitious people blamed the \"death strip\" on a nearby headless statue that sat on a hill overlooking the area. It occurred to me, a realist, that it was one of the few sections of the highway that did not run straight. If you think of it carefully, from the Churchill-Roosevelt Highway entering/exiting Port of Spain, the Uriah Butler and Hochoy highways run almost straight, without corners. The first corner is on the approach to the Freeport flyoverand there have been several horrible accidents there. On the South-bound section, several speeding vehicles \"straightened\" the corner by flying through the space between the two flyovers. They landed 20 or so feet below, on the Freeport Mission Road, many with fatal consequences. I recall one accident in which the vehicle that \"flew\" off the flyover landed on a taxi, killing one occupant. Several fatalities have occurred in that vicinity over the years. The second, more dangerous corner is on the approach to Claxton Bay. Motorists on the South-bound carriageway face not only a sharp corner, but a fairly steep, downhill gradient as well. One can imagine, therefore, what can happen when a motorist is speeding on that approach, and loses concentration for a split-second. He would fly across the median and should he miss the stout pillars that support the flyover, end up crossing the northbound carriageway. Travelling in the opposite direction there is also a gradient and corner, but the former is not that steep. What these features signal to any sober motorist is that you need to be extra-cautious on approaching the Claxton Bay flyover. One should moderate one's speed, grip the steering wheel with both hands, and be ready to apply brakes if that becomes necessary. Such precautions are even more of an imperative given the speed that modern vehicles constructed with flimsy alloys can attain. Add drunkenness or being sleepy to the equation, and what you have is a recipe for disaster. The Express editorial last Friday also correctly identified another dangerthe use of cellular phones while driving. In many ways the cellphone is more dangerous to humankind than a blessing. Many motorists, mainly the young and inexperienced, seem to be glued to these devices when they are driving. Some even send text messages while driving! Few have hands-free kits that at least mitigate the dangers of talking while driving. Experienced drivers know that once one wheel of these fast-but-flimsy vehicles loses traction, that's it. The vehicle spins out of control, and the rest is bloody history. Sensible drivers know other than lack of concentration, it's almost impossible to lose control of a vehiclebarring, say, a blown tyre or dropping into a huge pothole. Yet, whenever we hear of accidents that are claiming lives and maiming more people, there is always the report: the driver lost control of the vehicle. Bull, I say. Driving anywhere in Trinidad, from the most remote districts to those with heavy traffic, has become a hazardous venture. In my autumn years, I now have to keep peering into my rear-view mirrors, look ahead of me and try to pre-determine what some fool might do, check the shoulder for some jackass speeding on it. In fact, within recent times, I even look at traffic approaching in the opposite direction. Carnage on the nation's roads is cause for concern. Runaway vehicles are worse than runaway crime. In the latter, if the criminal is caught, at least he or she is brought to justice, maybe jailed. On the nation's roadways, criminals can kill innocent people and drive away without even stopping. I have long fulminated against the archaic traffic laws that offer incentives to reckless motorists rather than punish them. Imagine having to pay a fine of $200 for driving on the shoulder of the highway, or a similar amount for drag-racing. After last week's deadly accident at Claxton Bay, Roger Ganesh, Director of Highways, visited the area to see what can be done to curb the carnage. What he needs to tell Minister Colm Imbert is that implementation of the breathalyser legislation is more important than dreaming of a rapid rail system. Fines for dangerous driving should be punitive, not puny! CCTV cameras at these \"danger zones\" will help capture road-criminals. Seize their vehicles and impound them at police stations: they are sure to find them missing parts and accessories when they retrieve them! Implement a \"points\" system, a \"highways hotline\" so law-abiding motorists can report dangerous activities on the nation's roads. Too many innocent people are paying with their lives and limbs for the sins of lawless motorists. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-faa-says-its-airworthy---ministry-responds-to/article_ba7be6ac-45a6-11e9-a554-cb505b72fdff.html", "TITLE": " 'The FAA says its airworthy' - Ministry responds to Boeing Max jitters ", "DATE": "Mar 13, 2019 ", "CONTENT": "The Boeing 737 Max 8 The Boeing 737 Max 8 The Ministry of Works is responding to criticism and concern that it has not acted with urgency to ban airlines flying into the Piarco International Airport on the Boeing 737 Max 8, and halt procurement of this model aircraft by Caribbean Airlines as a result of two catastrophic crashes involving the airplane. The Ministry says it continues to be guided by the Trinidad and Tobago Civil Aviation Authority (TTCAA) which is mindful of the information being circulated in the public domain. \u201cThe TTCAA notes from media reports that the accident is being actively investigated by the relevant authorities. As such, neither the MOWT nor the TTCAA can engage in speculation over the cause of the accident or take premature action until it has reason to believe that the safety of the Boeing 737 Max 8 flight is compromised\u201d. The Ministry said that the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) of the United States signaled its confidence in the safety of the Boeing 737 MAX jetliner. \u201cThe FAA issued a global notice of \u201ccontinued airworthiness\u201d conveying that, there isn\u2019t conclusive evidence so far to link the loss of the Ethiopian Airlines 737 MAX 8 on Sunday to the fatal Lion Air disaster involving the same jet model in October 2018\u201d said the Works and Transport ministry. The Ministry called on the public to be guided by facts and not irresponsible, emotional rhetoric and wishes to emphasize that the safety of all citizens and commuters to Trinidad and Tobago will remain a top priority in the procurement of air vessels\u2019. Caribbean Airlines (CAL) is not currently flying the aircraft model in question, and its fleet comprises Boeing 737-800s which are among the safest airplanes in the world. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/more-oil-gas-leaks-in/article_1b890933-6d1c-571b-bdee-3af9751425dd.html", "TITLE": " More oil, gas leaks in 2014 ", "DATE": "Apr 7, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "On a fateful December day when Christmas shopping occupied the minds of most people, a 16-inch diameter sea line broke at the State-owned refinery, sending a rush of black fuel oil into the Gulf of Paria and along the south-western coastline. The effect of that spill is still being felt today by fisherfolk and people in poor coastal communities. The Express takes a close look at the chain of events that led to this country's worst environmental disaster in history. This is the fourth in a series of articles by Camini Marajh, head, Express Investigative Desk. Petrotrin's continued failure to follow its own risk-assessment warnings after the disastrous events of last December 17 has led to several new oil and gas leaks for this year already, Express investigations have found. The oil giant's failure to follow the 2010 Hapuarachchi mechanical integrity blueprint for refinery safety and continued use of aged infrastructure with identified hazards saw new leaks opening up on a three-inch butane line (early January), No. 27 sea line (a vapour return line, also in January), a flange leak on No. 22 sea line (gas oil, also in January), leaking expansion joint on No. 25 sea line (gasoline, early February), corrosion holes on sea line No. 61 (fuel oil) on March 31 and corrosion hole on sea line No. 21 (motor gasoline) on April 2. Company-issued Inspection Advice Tickets (IATs) for some of the problematic pipelines show some of the same vulnerabilities identified in the 2010 Mechanical Integrity Report for the refinery's marine infrastructure and a December 27, 2013 IAT for the failed No. 10 sea line, specifically\u2014failed maintenance, severe corrosion, delayed inspections and leaking expansion joints, flanges and valves, among other things. The leaks are said to be \"negligible\". As reported in Part I of this series, the State-owned oil and gas company overlooked multiple safety warnings, including a spate of negligible leaks on its pipelines and its own recommendations to replace severely corroded marine infrastructure, including its No. 10 sea line which failed dramatically on December 17. Documents obtained by this newspaper reveal that Petrotrin's maintenance scorecard has been less than exemplary. In the case of No. 27 sea line, identified as a medium-risk line by Gamini Hapuarachchi, Petrotrin's former Inspection Engineering head, the company neglected to do a crucial inspection in 2011. The IAT for No. 27 found an entire section of pipe resting on the ground without the requisite pipe support or protective safety wrapping. It noted that about \"150-inches of the line is severely corroded and covered with debris\" and a substantial number of flanges were \"severely corroded\" at the bottom. It found mechanical damage and sections that were so \"severely deteriorated\" it showed signs of \"crevice corrosive\". The company-issued IAT for No. 25 on February 7 revealed \"severe external corrosion under loose and deteriorated (safety) wrapping\" and several leaking expansion joints. And, as with No. 10 sea line, the primary degradation driver in all of the failed pipelines, including No. 15, No. 22, No. 25, No 27, and No. 61, was identified as \"external corrosion\". No. 15, another high-risk fuel oil line, failed on December 26. A section of the 12-inch diameter line collapsed into the sea after a support hanger gave way. That spill was contained in the Pointe-a-Pierre Harbour. In the case of No. 61, small line leaks developed into corrosion holes, according to persons with knowledge of the situation. This leak was also reported to have been contained in the harbour area. A corrosion hole was also identified as the problem with the April 2 leak on sea line No. 21. Pipe stress analysis and other integrity pipeline tests conducted by Hapuarachchi on failed sections of sea lines at the Petrotrin refinery found that: \"if a failure should occur, it is assumed that the mode of failure of these lines being that of a corrosion hole.\" More pipeline integrity issues also forced the February 11 closure of the company's Lube Oil Jetty, sources have disclosed. Critical lines which move hazardous hydrocarbon product were scheduled for urgent maintenance work after safety hazards were flagged. The company's own investigative report into the events leading to the No.10 failure found that the accident happened because of Petrotrin's own careless actions. Process Engineer Mervyn Cummings, the company man appointed as lead investigator, found that the state oil and gas company has been operating for years without critical spare parts like expansion joints or any staff in its Defect Elimination Section of the Reliability Engineering Department. He noted with concern the Petrotrin practice of allowing temporary fixes to become permanent fixtures. In a business culture where safety plays second fiddle to bottom line, Cummings found an absence of documented work plans or Management of Change (MOC) documents for change-outs of expansion joints and other repairs in violation of industry standards. He found what was supposed to be a temporary fix in 2002 on a sea line still in place 13 years later. His review of MOC documents for port operations from 2008 to January this year turned up a pipe spool (temporary replacement for failed expansion joint) doing hard overtime on the job. He said Petrotrin's Port Maintenance Superintendent, in office since May 2012, had previously requested the replacement of all the expansion joints because of the high incidence of leaks that \"are increasingly difficult to stop.\" He found instances where glands were tightened so much that the underside of the joints became deformed. Cummings pointed to the safety hazards related to extended use of pipe spools which do not possess any thermal expansion capability. He said this can cause the pipeline to move and create strain on the stationary section. In effect, exceed the design capabilities of the line, he said. As reported previously, the IAT on No. 10 listed several leaking expansion joints, valves and flanges. The ticket issued on No.15 also found leaking flanges and mechanical damage to the line. \"Pile Bent 30: the back to back support was severely deformed and knife-edge thin,\" according to the company-issued IAT. He found that the Hapuarachchi integrity management plan was not working as the safety blueprint intended. \"The failure of No.10 sea line could have been averted if the condition of these lines and the piping supports had been assessed/evaluated by the competent personnel basis the schedule proposed in the inspection report on the mechanical integrity of the sea lines produced by the Inspection Department in 2010 (016-2010) and corrective action taken as a result,\" Admitting to technical expertise \"limitations\" of the four-member team and the short time frame set for the report, Cummings urged Petrotrin to conduct further expert study on the matter and to review its design and maintenance practices. He also urged that equipment identified as medium or high-risk should be taken out of service until it is declared safe and fit for service by the competent experts. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/brink-of-disaster-waiting-to-happen/article_cc510230-24e7-5a97-9c39-dd485e071a88.html", "TITLE": " Brink of disaster waiting to happen ", "DATE": "Mar 25, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "delivered report: Clement Sankat delivered report: Clement Sankat A letter only meant to be seen by the doctors and managers of the San Fernando General Hospital (SFGH) has revealed an alarming and unchecked collapse in the quality of medical care that has led to the deaths of an untold number of patients. Among the disturbing disclosuresthe absence of a full-time pathologist, microbiologist haematologist and no neurosurgeon at the nation's largest public health institution, a situation that has led to people with brain injuries being rushed to the Port of Spain General Hospital, only to be returned by ambulance, and dying on the way back. The letter was penned by Dr Steve Budhooram, the hospital's head of department, General Surgery, who wrote \"the public needs to know not to sustain a head injury in South Trinidad\". His appeal comes in the wake of the death after a Ceasarean section of Chrystal Boodoo-Ramsoomair and the decision by the board of the South-West Regional Health Authority (SWRHA) to suspend five doctors and five nurses involved in her care. The letter, which at times took on a tone of desperation and despair, was addressed to the hospital's acting medical director, Dr Anand Chatoorgoon; board chairman, Dr Lackram Bodoe; board executive medical director, Dr Akenath Misir; nursing manager, Betty Ann Pilgrim; acting general manager of nursing, Geraldine Lewis; the heads of hospital departments and consultants attached to the department of surgery. The letter was sent last Tuesday in the midst of another crisis at the hospital, with elective surgeries cancelled and patients crowding the medical wards because doctors, concerned they were in breach of Health Ministry policy, were spending more time assessing and treating patients at the Accident and Emergency department and on the wards and delaying the release of improving patients, in an effort to ensure they were not accused of medical negligence. Doctors said they were fearful they, too, would be disciplined or suspended. The issue was said to be \"resolved\" on Thursday with the intervention of Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar, with the Medical Professionals Association of Trinidad and Tobago (MPATT) agreeing to a review of the systems at the San Fernando General Hospital. But Dr Budhooram's letter outlines deep and complex problems. He noted in the letter that during a recent meeting, his department took the unanimous decision \"to adhere to strict, current, accepted guidelines in the management of surgical patients. No more will we be coerced with taking shortcuts and make do with what is available at the San Fernando General Hospital, thereby setting up the personnel in the department for lawsuits, suspensions and even criminal action taken against them. For too long, the (SWRHA) and even the Ministry of Health have blatantly disregarded our call for better facilities and conditions to optimally treat surgical patients\". Dr Budhooram said the shortage of staff is chronic, with his department operating with five firms (medical teams) but only three registrarsdoctors with advanced training in a specialist field. He wrote, \"We are now told that the two acting registrars have to revert to senior house officer (doctors training in specialist field) as they have no postgraduate degree. It would, indeed, be a ridiculous situation if a specialist medical officer has to supervise the senior house officer in the middle of the night to drain an abscess, as the Ministry of Health dictates.\" He said there was a nursing shortage in the Obstetrics and Gynaecology (O&G) department \"We are also on the brink of a disaster waiting to happen. International standards dictate that on a surgical ward, there should be one nurse to five patients. In the department, this does not happen on the afternoon and night shifts. There might be approximately three nurses to 30 patients, with the ratio being even greater on weekends and public holidays. We will no longer tolerate this. We have decided to tailor to elective list to meet the nursing demands of the evening and night shifts.\" Budhooram said on the surgical wards, there was a shortage of basic supplies over the past year. \"Erratic supply of syringes, blood bottles, needles, gloves, incontinent pads is the order of the day. We are expected to work with this. We will not continue this way,\" he wrote. On the shortage of monitoring devices, Budhooram wrote, \"The wish lists...were promptly denied citing financial problems. This is unacceptable and only serves to frustrate the department\". With no neurosurgeon assigned to the hospital, Budhooram said patients have died for lack of neurosurgical care. \"Even more scandalous is that emergent patients (those with life-threatening injuries) are transported to POSGH [Port of Spain General Hospital] for neurosurgical operations and promptly placed in the ambulance for transport back to SFGH, only to die on the way or on arrival at hospital. I told the ex-CEO, Paula Chester-Cumberbatch, in a meeting that this is not bad medicine, but barbaric medicine. Nothing was done.\" Budhooram wrote that at a recent meeting of the heads of department with Bodoe and Misir, the assurance was given that the chief medical officer, Dr Anton Cumberbatch, was dealing with this problem. \"I see no end in sight, but the public needs to know not to sustain a head injury in South Trinidad\". Budhooram stated with no gastroenterologist for four years, surgeons were unable to do endoscopies (internal non-surgical procedures) for patients with (gastrointestinal) bleeds as vouchers have not been given out for these endoscopic examinations to be done privately. \"We have reverted to the old days to do surgery for all (gastrointestinal) bleeds when the majority can be done endoscopically, with no surgery. We have also had to go back twenty-five years to explore common bile ducts as ERCP (a technique that enables the doctor to diagnose problems with the liver, gallbladder, bile ducts and pancreas) is not available here. \"What is even more distressing is when (Bodoe) informs us that a gastroenterologist who is a T&T national has applied for the post a few months ago, however, our Human Resources department, with their usual tardiness, knowing the urgent need for this doctor, continues to drag their feet.\" Budhooram wrote that there was even a shortage of qualified radiologists. \"Imagine waiting six weeks for a CT (computer-assisted tomography scan), MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) report long after the patient has been operated on. What a financial waste.\" Budhooram wrote that he has worked at the hospital for 34 years, and the problems have been festering for too long. \"It has finally erupted in the faces of these non-performers with disastrous consequences.\" He wrote, \"We are at our lowest ebb. Patient care is being dictated by the total inefficiencies of the authorities at the SWRHA and Ministry of Health. We have towed the line, \"cut corners and stretched the limited and archaic services to the limit. Given the consequences and the debacle which took place in the O&G department, we are not prepared to go that way. I am, therefore, informing you that we will demand from the authorities the necessary services to give safe and optimal care to the patient.\" TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/management-changes-trumped-safety/article_f8cd359a-f402-57f3-948a-5b677e3121d1.html", "TITLE": " Management changes trumped safety ", "DATE": "May 9, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "cleaning up: Oil spill in La Brea. cleaning up: Oil spill in La Brea. On a fateful December day when Christmas shopping occupied the minds of most people, a 16-inch diameter sea line broke at the State-owned refinery, sending a rush of black fuel oil into the Gulf of Paria and along the south-western coastline. The effect of that spill is still being felt today by fisherfolk and people in poor coastal communities. The Sunday Express takes a close look at the chain of events that led to this country's worst environmental disaster. This is the tenth in a series of articles by Camini Marajh, head, Express Investigative Desk A revolving cast of oil executives at the State-owned energy giant Petrotrin each played a part in the persistent failure to comply with mandatory safety codes and their own risk assessment process, including a package of Shell-bought Risk Based Inspection (RBI) systems. Continuing Sunday Express investigations found that the State's oil executives used selective risk assessment results and temporary fixes to hide the gravity and scale of aging facilities that\u2014in large part\u2014are as old as the refinery's operations. As reported in last Sunday's paper, weak regulation by the State oversight agencies and government complicity allowed Petrotrin to exploit the weaknesses in the system, hide the truth about its pipeline integrity management problems and ignore repeated safety warnings of its own technical experts to the detriment of life and the environment. Inspection reports, board minutes, internal investigations into accidental deaths, blow-outs, bad welds, leaks and spills, and other company documents obtained by the Sunday Express detailed a culture of shortcuts and complacency where loyalty and friendship counts far more than competence, adherence to the rules and accountability. A review of company data and interviews with current and former Petrotrin officials reveal that despite a plethora of cutting-edge systems, blueprints and pipeline diagnostics to improve its risk management and spill-trajectory modelling, the oil giant failed to meet its own standards and the requirements of the law. One element running through the Petrotrin narrative is the management failure to follow the specific safety recommendations of its own experts. Persons familiar with the situation say this is why the No 10 accident and subsequent oil and gas spills were inevitable. \"It was only a matter of time,\" said one insider, noting that the accidents will continue to pile up until and unless Petrotrin takes care of all of its identified and outstanding high-risk mechanical integrity problems. As reported in Monday's Express, Petrotrin's push for higher profit margins continues to put workers' safety at risk. If December 17 was a wake-up call for the slumbering oil giant, it is not evident by how it conducts its business which continues to put profits before safety. Petrotrin's own data suggests that the company made a lot of avoidable mistakes on the way to the December 17 bunker fuel spill and even then failed to manage it properly. Petrotrin insiders are still scratching their heads over how the company failed to follow its own historical data on marine spill-trajectory modelling which show a predicted pathway from Pointe-a-Pierre to the south-western peninsula and its apparent inability \u2014after a near 100 years in the oil business\u2014to differentiate crude oil from bunker fuel oil. The State company which failed to ask for help, rebuffed the help that was offered by bpTT and then lied about almost everything else, including the size of the spill, ignored all of the evidence that the oil was headed to the south-western coastline and made no effort to protect the shoreline of La Brea. The company stayed on script that identified spills at Pointe-a-Pierre, Riser Platform 5 and Platform 17 were all \"successfully contained\" and that the black oil washing up on tar slicked beaches along the coastline belonged to somebody else. It was all a mystery, according to Petrotrin, which had full knowledge before 6 o'clock on the morning of December 17 that it had over 7,000 barrels of unaccounted-for oil somewhere out in the Gulf of Paria. Moreover, it claimed its own laboratory analysis identified the weathered samples taken from La Brea and other beaches along the south-western coastline as crude. The Institute of Marine Affairs (IMA) tests called it in as a match for the missing 7,554 barrels of Petrotrin bunker fuel oil days later. Petrotrin's deceit is perhaps best summed up in this response from manager, Health Safety and the Environment (HSE), Shyam Dyal, who up until a year ago was deputy chairman of the Environmental Management Authority (EMA). In a December comment about the source of the La Brea oil, the HSE boss said: \"It is a question that is currently being asked\u2014how did the oil get on the La Brea beach We cannot see a direct link to the Trinmar incidents and the Pointe-a-Pierre incident at this point in time. We are still continuing investigations.\" Perhaps the company didn't look hard enough at its own marine spill trajectory data. Had the HSE manager and Petrotrin top brass looked at its own data, including pictures taken during aerial fly-bys over the affected areas at 11.30 a.m. on December 18, it would have noticed the vast column of oil, about 1,000 feet long and 100 feet wide, about three to four miles west of the refinery Berth No.1 and the oily sheen sighted around the Oropouche Bank north of La Brea. The company which sprayed about 1,705 gallons of the chemical dispersant, Coreexit, as part of its containment effort over the polluted Gulf of Paria area, contended that its aerial and marine surveillance failed to detect oil on the surface. Industry analysts question why Petrotrin expected to find oil on the surface when its chosen chemical, Corexit, was known to sink oil below the surface. Further, company logs related to the 2 a.m. fuel bunker loading operation that went disastrously wrong show that at 8.30 a.m. on December 17, the oil spill was moving in a south-westerly direction. Asked to explain the company's failure to shore off protected coastline given all of the available data known to company officials, Petrotrin's president, Khalid Hassanali, in an e-mail response to the Sunday Express, said: \"Commencing on December 17, 2013 and continuing over the days following, our operations were impacted by several incidents. \"In addition to having to treat with the spill at Pointe-a-Pierre, we were treating with what was then considered to be a different spill at La Brea (no nexus was yet established between the Pointe-a-Pierre and La Brea incidents) as well as other incidents in our Trinmar fields. \"Our response to the specific incidents, placement of booms etc were guided by the results of our oil spill-trajectory models and the situations as they developed on the ground.\" But historical data on environmental parameters such as water temperature, wind speed, wave heights and oceanic conditions specific to the Gulf of Paria suggests a spill trajectory from Pointe-a-Pierre would more than likely travel in a south-westerly direction. Hassanali said Petrotrin relied on its oil spill-trajectory modelling to come up with its own analysis of how to respond to the spill. \"Our oil spill-trajectory model indicated that, given the circumstances, there was a 95 per cent probability that any fuel that escaped would have been on the surface and both the aerial and marine surveys conducted did not reveal any oil slicks leaving Pointe-a-Pierre. This is why no nexus was initially established between the incident at Pointe-a-Pierre and the spill at La Brea.\" What has emerged so far suggests that Petrotrin has been less than candid with the national community, was slow to respond to the spill and then tried to lie its way out of the impending catastrophe. As reportedly previously in this series, a lot of the decisions made have been driven by the need to minimise the company's liability. Question is, who is going to hold Petrotrin to account given the State's complicity in this affair The Decision Makers responsible for maintaining mechanical integrity of plant and equipment: The board of directors, led by former energy minister in the Panday administration, Lindsay Gillette, President \u2013 Khalid Hassanali Vice-President, Refinery and Marketing \u2013 Mado Bachan Senior Manager, Refinery \u2013 Luke McSween HSE Manager \u2013 Shyam Dyal Manager, Inspection Services \u2013 Edwin Caines Senior Superintendent, Marine Services \u2013 Collin Piper Superintendent of Inspection Services \u2013 Savitry Rajpaul Maintenance Manager \u2013 Kishore Jhagroo Manager Engineering Services \u2013 Roopchan Balkaran Continues on Sunday TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/new-rapid-response-team-coming/article_6a453bfd-60e1-5288-90d5-7be775360b21.html", "TITLE": " New rapid response team coming ", "DATE": "Jun 26, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "TWO weeks after a National Petroleum fuel tanker overturned and spilled gasoline on the Solomon Hochoy Highway causing a major traffic gridlock for several hours, the Office of Disaster Preparedness and Management (ODPM) is in the process of establishinga new response team. The ODPM, through its communications officer Dike Noel had initially said it was not mandated to be involved in such an emergency. However, a media release signed by the ODPM's chief executive officer Dr Stephen Ramroop yesterday stated that the National Extreme Incident Response Team(NEIRT) \" will adequately address all gaps in the incident command system and information flow.\" A meeting was held yesterday at the ODPM's office in Tacarigua with all first responder agencies. Ramroop said the policy for NEIRT was already drafted and will be sent to Cabinet for approval. On June 14, the midday crash caused a five-hour long traffic pile-up affecting tens of thousands of people, causing multiple minor accidentson secondary roads choked with vehicles and chaos outside many schools. The problem was only resolved after nightfall. Noel had said the ODPM was not expected to get involved in the emergency response. He said, \"It was not something that we were mandated to get involved in...If it was on a larger scale then we would have gotten involved and immediately coordinatedthings a bit differently, in a different measure.\" But Roger Ganesh, director of Highways in the Ministry of Works and Transport,who visited the area along with Works Minister Jack Warner on the day of the crash, criticisedthe ODPM saying they were the ones who were supposed to be coordinating the response. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/scandal-of-princes-town-police-station/article_aef81d62-dd9d-55df-b2a1-fd245b01cbe8.html", "TITLE": " Scandal of Princes Town Police Station ", "DATE": "Jan 11, 2014 ", "CONTENT": " The family of Barrackpore resident Manohar Sonnylal is owed an apology by the acting Commissioner of Police and, indeed, by the entire justice system of this country for a denial of justice. On Friday, more than three years after Mr Sonnylal was killed in a vehicular accident, the case against the defendant, Timothy De Leon, was dismissed after the police officer who had laid the charge failed to turn up in court. In dismissing the matter at the Princes Town Magistrates Court, Magistrate Deborah Quintyne noted that January 10 had been listed as the final date on which the matter would be heard. In the circumstances, she felt obliged to dismiss the case against Mr De Leon who had been charged with dangerous driving leading to Mr Sonnylals death in 2011. When asked, officers gave conflicting information regarding the whereabouts of the officer who had laid the charge. Such police disaster is magnified to mass proportions at the nearby Princes Town Police Station whose notoriety was outlined in yesterdays Sunday Express. This stations sins range from the infamous case of the rats who ate the cocaine evidence to a series of prisoner escapes, several of whom later claimed that they bribed officers to facilitate their getaway. The most recent charge against the station comes from 18-year-old Jamerson John who claims officers stripped him to his underwear and set fire to his genitals after he refused to admit to a robbery. If there is a place crying out for a thorough investigation it is the Princes Town Police Station. All the signs indicate a rotten state of affairs there. Without prejudicing the legal matters involving the teenager, it would be fair to say that the multiple incidents warrant a sharp focus on the management and officers at Princes Town station going back several years. We shudder to think about the impact of all this on public confidence in the officers of this station. The responsibility for the integrity of police operations throughout the country falls squarely on the shoulders of acting Commissioner of Police Stephen Williams. After apologising to the Sonnylal family, he must explain why the system failed to ensure the prosecuting officers presence in court on Friday. While this is far from being an isolated incident, it will provide the public with some insight into the institutional weaknesses that allow the continuing perversion of justice by absent officers. The people of Trinidad and Tobago cannot continue to be robbed of justice by police failures which could originate from any number of sources including mismanagement, poor communication systems or outright corruption. To be fair to the acting CoP, he inherited a poisoned chalice. These are long-standing problems that have defied one Commissioner after another. But he is in the job now and there is no denying that in applying for it, he would have felt himself adequately equipped. The Princes Town Police Station is one of the opportunities waiting for him to prove that he has something of what the job takes. Bullet Banker owned by Shivam Maharaj won by 1 1/4 lengths from Xposed, Cat Dancer and Dutchman in a good 1:04.4. \u0097 Photo: JERMAINE CRUICKSHANK Stop eating up yourself about what could have been. Just be grateful for what was, and hope that lessons are learnt from the tragic death of Jizelle Salandy. In a country that obsesses over rewards, financial or otherwise, for our prominent achievers in all walks of life, the greatest, most enduring tribute to the multi-titled world champion female boxer would be for all who treat the roadways as a drag racing strip or their vehicles as a means to vent their frustrations to do one simple thing: slow down. But that's not going to happen, is it It's much easier to put up a plaque, dedicate some facility or other or create an award here or there in the fallen heroine's name rather than undertake a concerted, comprehensive campaign that could have much more beneficial long-term consequences for the nation, and especially a younger generation, which, like all younger generations since the dawn of mankind, is defined by a belief that they are almost immortal and immune to tragedy. That is until something like this happens, and we all wonder why. So it has been, so it is, so it always will be. Call it destiny. Call it hardenness. But it would be nice to think that people would be more concerned with acting responsibly and urging others under their sphere of influence to do the same instead of putting flowers and heartfelt notes next to a so-called \"killer\" pillar that, as best as I can recall, has never moved from its position under the NP flyover in more than 25 years. Every once in a while a society goes through something like this when a prominent personality is shown to be flesh and blood and very, very fragile, just like the rest of us. Rather than being preoccupied with building shrines and bestowing sainthood on people like Diana Spencer, for example, wouldn't it be more productive to use the positive aspects of such deceased celebrities to make us recognise that every one of us, if given the opportunity, can be heroes in our own right, even if it doesn't bring with it fame, glory and unbelievable riches English society, not just English football, was rocked by the death of eight members of the celebrated \"Busby Babes\" of Manchester United when the team's plane crashed on take-off following a refuelling stop in Munich, Germany, on February 6, 1958. This team of brilliant young players, under the management of Sir Matt Busby, were league champions two years in a row and had qualified for the semi-finals of the European cup when tragedy struck. Among the victims was Duncan Edwards, who died 15 days after the crash at the age of 21. Almost 51 years after the disaster, those who saw the centre-half in action maintain that Edwards, who made his senior England international debut at 18, would have been one of his country's greatest players had he lived. Pretty much the same was said of cricketer Collie Smith, the outstanding Jamaica and West Indies all-rounder who died in a vehicular accident on September 9, 1959 in England at the age of 26. Smith had marked his Test debut with innings of 44 and 104 against the might of Australia's Ray Lindwall and Keith Miller at Sabina Park in 1955, and combined with his useful off-spin and infectious enthusiasm for the game, was being compared with the rising all-round star of the time, Garfield Sobers. Smith and Sobers had actually become great friends in their brief time together in the West Indies squad and the loss was made all the more painful for Sobers as he was in the car driven by another West Indian player, the Barbadian fast bowler Tom Dewdney, when the crash claimed the life of the ebullient Jamaican. Ayrton Senna had scaled the heights of Formula One motor racing as champion driver three times already when he met his end on May 1 during the third race of the 1994 season at the Imola racetrack in San Marino. Yet it was because of the Brazilian's fiery brilliance and tempestuous duels with Frenchman Alain Prost on the track, and captivating personality off it, that his homeland mourned his passing at 34 as a national tragedy. His demise left the world of motorsport speculating as to whether Germany's Michael Schumacher, who won his first Formula One title that year, would have been able to dominate the sport so completely for the next decade had Senna still been on the starting grid. At least they all tasted success in varying degrees on the international stage: Edwards, Smith, Senna and Salandy. But what of someone who seemed destined to achieve so much until we realised that his fate was written differently from what most expected Every year in the cricket season, QRC old boys get together for the annual Shirvan Pragg Memorial Match, paying tribute to the 19-year-old left-handed wrist-spinner and batsman who was the backseat victim of a vehicular accident in 1982, mere weeks after he had returned home from a successful tour of England as vice-captain of a powerful West Indies under-19 squad led by Roger Harper. Despite his tremendous success at youth level, it is debatable whether Pragg would have ever had the chance to establish himself at the highest level for the West Indies, given that this was at the every height of Caribbean dominance by speed. In any event, just like the others, it wasn't meant to be. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/staying-in-the-fast-lane-of-lng-exports/article_d3140a3f-07b0-550d-a546-b7c0ea97ce66.html", "TITLE": " Staying in the Fast lane of LNG exports ", "DATE": "Jun 27, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "President of BG Trinidad and Tobago, Derek Hudson President of BG Trinidad and Tobago, Derek Hudson Royal Dutch Shell, the world's second largest international oil company (IOC), has implicitly supported the view of the International Energy Agency (IEA) that a \"new golden age\" of natural gas awaits us a thesis explored in Energy Insider last week by its decision to proceed with what will be the world's first commercial floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) project. The 480-metre long vessel will be able to liquefy and store natural gas at the rate of 3.6 million tonnes a year (a little more than Atlantic's trains two and three down at Point Fortin in southwest Trinidad) and will be positioned over the Prelude gas discovery in the Browse Basin off Western Australia. The vessel is being constructed by Samsung Heavy Industries in South Korea and should be in place by 2016, five years from now. There are said to be at least 12 more FLNG units that have been approved for use by other IOC's, and probably for NOC's (national oil companies) too and are awaiting final investment go-ahead before the shipyards get their confirmed orders. Why is this development important For the very good reason that it will make gas discoveries that are normally considered \"stranded\" difficult to commercialise for reasons of remoteness and thus inaccessible by pipelines now monetiseable. Companies that have had the misfortune, as they saw it, to find such gas will now be able, thanks to FLNG, to exploit it and to participate in IEA's predicted \"golden age\". Mind you, FLNG will not be coming cheap. Though Shell has not specified the cost of its historic project, industry sources have suggested it could be between US$5-US$10 billion. But this will undoubtedly be reduced as shipyards receive more orders for FLNG vessels and if traded gas is going to be as much in demand between now and 2035 as the IEA says rising to 5.1 trillion cubic metres, 1.8 trillion cm more than today, providing 25 per cent of the world's energy mix then it should not be difficult to achieve payback on such an investment. The \"new golden age of gas\" theory is well supported by a number of current developments, which will encourage the usage, and trading, of the commodity. These include: 1. The fact that the construction of LNG import terminals continues at a steady pace (with the probable exception of the United States, which, as I have written constantly here in recent weeks, now sets itself more as a gas exporter, certainly of LNG, than a gas importer, because of the increase in domestic gas production). Twenty-one LNG import facilities are currently being built, to join the 94 already in existence in 23 countries. The operators of those terminals clearly don't expect to be receiving coal or crude oil! 2. Because of the dangers of a radiation leak should an accident befall any nuclear power station, as recently occurred at the Fukushima Dai-ichi plant in Japan following the earthquake and tsunami, the world is rapidly falling out of love with nuclear. Germany has taken the decision to close all its 17 nuclear plants by 2022, which currently provides it with 23 per cent of its electric power. Other countries have chosen not to go ahead with nuclear energy at all, such as nearby Venezuela. Japan itself, which obtains over 30 per cent of its energy from nuclear power, has shut other plants since the disaster and guess what alternative it has turned to Why, LNG, of course. In April, Japan imported more LNG than it has ever done before, bringing in seven million tonnes to make up for the shortfall in nuclear generated electricity. Japan's LNG imports are set to rise by 19 per cent this year, according to analysts. 3. Of all the energy alternatives to nuclear, gas is favoured on the basis of its climate change credentials alone. It does emit heat-trapping gases when burned but 100 per cent less than coal and significantly less than oil. Of course, renewable energy (RE) emits no harmful substances at all but RE is not expected to be a major source of energy in the world, even by 2035. Gas, by contrast, will rise to become 25 per cent of the global energy mix, thanks to its adoption in electricity generation by the likes of China, India, the Middle East and South America. 4. A potential area of growth in gas demand that has been largely overlooked so far is the use of LNG as a fuel in shipping. As one shipping expert recently pointed out: \"Natural gas has substantial environmental benefits over oil-based bunkers, in that it contains virtually no sulpher and produces less CO2.\" The Maritime Authority in Denmark recently commissioned a study on how an LNG refueling infrastructure could be established in Northern Europe to cater to the increasing number of ships expected to opt for this fuel. So let's put all this in the context of Trinidad and Tobago, shall we We are already a major international trader of LNG, in fact, the seventh biggest in the world after only 12 years in the business. We will continue to profitably access the US market, never mind the fall in the gas price there on the back of increased domestic production and will also be selling to many other countries. Derek Hudson, president of BG Trinidad and Tobago and a man who should certainly know about these matters, confidently states in the June issue of ENERGY Caribbean magazine that: \"BG, BP, RepsolYPF, NGC and the Trinidad and Tobago government, would not have made all those LNG investments in four trains just to see production suddenly stop in the next few years.\" Exactly. But far from \"stopping\", my thesis is that Trinidad and Tobago should be busily preparing itself for taking maximum advantage of the \"new golden age of gas\" and that requires us to remain in the fast lane of LNG exports (we may well be participating in pipeline gas too, but to a much more modest extent). The gas price challenge, particularly in the US, can be overcome with Atlantic's determination to be cost competitive, and there is no threat of a gas shortage because the exploration activity to be conducted in the North Coast blocks will and you can take that to the bank result in the discovery of additional reserves. The stumbling block, as I see it, is the reluctance so far of the Minister of Energy and Energy Affairs Carolyn Seepersad-Bachan to publicly commit herself to the continuation of the LNG trading business. But it is something she absolutely needs to do if the de-bottlenecking of the four Atlantic trains is to go ahead, if new initiatives like Centrica's are to receive the green light and if budding gas trading entrepreneurs like Aerogas Processors Ltd's George A B Naime are to have the confidence to find ways of going after the small gas trades market that, by hook or by crook, will eventually materialise in the wider Caribbean. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/risk-is-always-risky/article_c3d1501c-fb4b-5af0-944b-0a19a79047f1.html", "TITLE": " Risk is always risky ", "DATE": "Nov 15, 2010 ", "CONTENT": " A trader works on the floor just before the closing bell recently at the New York Stock Exchange. \u2013Photo: AFP A trader works on the floor just before the closing bell recently at the New York Stock Exchange. \u2013Photo: AFP Over the last two years, someone browsing through the financial news would have come across the phrases 'moral hazard' and 'too big to fail' every week on average. Moral hazard, very simplified, is that irritating guy who totalled his car somehow, insurance bought him an even nicer one, and there was still a bit left over for a trip to Tobago; of course, he was driving carelessly knowing that, in an accident, insurance would cover the costs. Essentially, moral hazard describes the risk created when some party can act without bearing the full weight of its actions in the event of a mishap. Knowing that 'Peter pays for Paul', Paul arguably takes risks where he should not, and acts irresponsibly, with few, if any, consequences to consider. To label some accident as moral hazard then, is to automatically cast aspersions on the supposed victim and to create speculation as to the cause of disaster. The concept of 'too big to fail' is one which the American government is working feverishly to disband. It characterises companies that are so integral to the financial system that any of their collapses would signify a mortal blow, if not a death sentence, to the global economy. With credit unions fearing collapse given their CLICO exposure this 'too big to fail' idea is of very real, very current importance to Trinidad and Tobago. When a financial institution reaches a certain critical mass and becomes the provider of investments to other significant financial institutions, it can create a situation where there is risk to the entire system. In local circumstances, extraneous details tend to intrude. T&T is a small village to USA's big city. The multi-billionaires on Wall Street who had millions slashed from their bonuses elicited little pity in the overall scheme of things. The pensioners who invested in CLICO are another story altogether. Public sympathy and a general cry of broken promises may or may not govern the actions that government takes. However, determining whether the fall of CL Financial and subsidiaries is a moral hazard or is simply a casualty in a global crisis is of more immediate importance at this time. The recent financial crisis in the developed world comprised two parts. Firstly, investor greed elicited levels of illiquidity that banks should have avoided. Secondly, underlying assets were fundamentally toxic with high levels of risk being repackaged more attractively. People with little or no incomes were given loans to buy houses. And investors were persuaded to invest in these loans as they were considered to be top quality assets; of course history has proven otherwise. In this regard, the United States differs drastically from T&T. A major cornerstone in the arguments proposed by the CL Financial (CLF) group is the solidity of most underlying assets and the intrinsic value of real estate in the long-term. While assets were definitely inflated pre-crisis, current methods of valuing them may be excessively cautious. Government's \"twenty-year certificates\" offer yields a present value between 58 and 65 cents to the dollar on average, a far cry from what investors expected (or still expect) to receive. What needs to be considered is that the bulk of assets on CLICO's balance sheet do not represent the same risks as the toxic securities that destroyed Bear, Lehman and Merrill, to name a few. There was a global demand for liquidity as creditors demanded their money back and our regional giant was caught in the crossfire. While we must expect CLF to take some responsibility for its high leverage and subsequent liquidity crisis, it was, to a large extent, a product of its environment. As with Long Term Capital Management (see Part 1), CL Financial was too sure and too extravagant, yet was also simply, unluckily caught in the cogs of the economic downswing. What emerged was a good, or not so good, old-fashioned run on the business. In a panic, investors demanded cash that was tied to long-term assets and the values of those assets plunged. Had certain events not conspired against it, the company might have kept its extreme leverage unnoticed and its assets might have appreciated above government's current bailout proposals. Yet, regardless of potential future asset value, at what point is it government's role to rescue a private company It has been suggested that systemic risk has passed and CL is no longer \"too big to fail\". One might pose questions about publicly traded companies that have theoretically lost more than 50 per cent market value in the last five years. Does government's role as lender of last resort include an obligation to the private investor In fact, will managers of investment funds and banks pursue outrageous profits because they know that taxpayers will insure their mistakes Thankfully, regulation and legislation has evolved to constrain and monitor any financial imprudence. Conclusively, the lesson that we should take from the downfall of regional and American great-has-beens, is one in risk. What seems too good to be true, most likely is. Both investors and financial regulators should pay marked attention to warning bells that have grown increasingly louder with the evolution of risk management. These \"once in a lifetime\" breakdowns of institutions that are \"too big to fail\" and their necessary bailouts have occurred with higher frequency and will continue to do so if flaws in risk management remain unaddressed.
