{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/vistabella-s-own-mining-disaster/article_760a7da4-d516-538f-8078-11dc6784f9ce.html", "TITLE": " Vistabella's own mining disaster ", "DATE": "Oct 23, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "BUILT ON SITE: The Roman Catholic Church in Vistabella which was built on the site of the mining disaster of 1904. BUILT ON SITE: The Roman Catholic Church in Vistabella which was built on the site of the mining disaster of 1904. ONE hundred and six years later, the story of 17 souls lost in a collapsed mine off Manjack Street, Vistabella, in December 1904, is being told again. The story has resurfaced, however, not because of the recent Chilean mining incident that seemed certain to end in disaster. That episode ended up this year's miracle story, with all 33 miners making it out alive after 69 days trapped underground because of the heroism of countless others. The tale is being told again, curiously, because of the collapse, two months ago, of the Pointe-a-Pierre Road in Vistabella, and the abandoning of three homes condemned by city officials. San Fernando Mayor Marlene Coudray said recently, \"At least three people hold the view that the mine could be responsible for the massive land slippage taking place near the Vistabella River.\" Vistabella lies on the northern extremities of San Fernando. In earlier times, it was home to East Indian immigrants assigned as labourers to work on Vistabella Sugar Estate, one of the largest in the San Fernando area. It had several names. East Indians called it Vista Beya (beautiful bay), the French called it Petit Bourgh (Little Town), San Fernandians called it Border Town, and it was the Spaniards who gave it the name Vista bella (a beautiful view). Apart from the Manjack Mine disaster, there was another event of historical importance to stamp collectors. The immigrants had only arrived in Trinidad a few years before some of them working on Vistabella Sugar Estate recovered a large brass bell from the Lady McLeod steamer in 1854, after it sank off the coast in Vistabella. On seeing the vessel sinking in the Gulf of Paria, they realised nothing could be done, but there were items of value on the steamer that could be saved. The bell was removed from the deck and carried ashore to the estate manager, George Lambie. Later they learned that the bell they recovered was from the steamer, a likeness of which was used on Trinidad's first postage stamp. The Lady McLeod stamp was designed and introduced in 1847 by the steamer's captain, David Bryce. Initially it was used as a receipt for transporting goods along the coastal towns. The stamp depicted a white ship on a blue background with the initials \"LMcL\" printed underneath. The Lady McLeod stamp has world recognition. The original was last seen in New York and its value was estimated at over US$2,000. The bell is kept in the foyer of the San Fernando City Council. Vistabella has a rich mineral resource called manjack, a type of pitchthe name possibly derived from the town of Manjack in the island of Madagascar, according to the historians. The manjack was first found in 1877 at Williamsville, but the biggest mine was found in 1898 in Vistabella. Following the discovery, extensive underground work started at the Vistabella mine, and continued until disaster struck. On December 17, 1904, while mining at a depth of 200 feet there was an explosion and 17 workers were killed and several injured. Entrance and exit was gained by using a ladder, and light was provided by gas lamp. The historians record that an explosion was heard between the fourth and fifh tunnels, which were some 200 feet from the surface. One man was thrown down as he shouted \"fire!\" Those at the main shaft experienced a rush of wind with the smell of gas coming up through the shaft. The workers panicked. As they struggled to reach the ladder they were affected either by fire or overcome by the gas. Altogether 17 workers perishedten Barbadians, five East Indians, one Grenadian and one Trinidadian. The manager of the mine made arrangements to bury the dead by supplying graves and coffins, and giving $12 to the representatives of each of the deceased. The government immediately ordered an enquiry, which took place on February 20, 1905. At the end of the sitting, the owners were charged with manslaughter and the matter heard before High Court judge Swan on April 17,1905. At the end of the trial, the owners of the mine were acquitted. Most of the workers and their families who were working on the mine belonged to a Baptist cult at Fabien Street, headed by High Priest Mellon. He told them it was no accident that 17 people were killed on December 17, and that they should leave the area, the story goes. They took his advice and moved to New Grant, near Princes Town. Years later, the site of the mining disaster was acquired by the Roman Catholic church. A church was built on the site and named St Andrew Kaggwa. It is recorded that Kaggwa, a Ugandan who became a Roman Catholic, was beheaded on January 17, 1887. After the church was built, a wall reinforced with 17 concrete columns was constructed to protect the integrity of the wall surrounding the church. Over time, Vistabella moved from a border town, to a district within the city of San Fernando. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/it-comes-to-us-all/article_f07d9f99-d3f5-5441-92a5-24d5fb13ed95.html", "TITLE": " It comes to us all ", "DATE": "Apr 12, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " In exactly six weeks I will be one year older and it seemed like only yesterday that I was venturing off into the world of work with my freshly minted degree in one hand and a bag of ambition in the other. Oh how time flies! and the truth is time does fly and as it soars on from day to day we may put on a few pounds get a grey hair or two and soon realise that we are not as young as we used to be. Time brings with it two inevitabilities- the longer we live the older we will become and the reality that we will not live forever. Most of us will be fortunate enough to reach retirement age and all of us will eventually die. Such is the nature of life. We each respond to time's gifts differently. Some may try to fight the effects of age by dying their hair, using anti-aging cream or leading a healthier lifestyle, and that's fine but regardless of who we are be it a neurosurgeon, economist, vegetarian, marathoner, priest or billionaire we will all one day come to the same end in life. The fortunate will one day retire but death will come to us all. Both of these circumstances require us to prepare financially, not just for ourselves but also for our loved ones. Retirement is the reward for years of hard work and it is a time that many of us plan to enjoy a leisurely life. In order for us to comfortably enjoy our Golden Years we must plan our financial affairs wisely. Interestingly, the term \"Golden Years\" comes from Greek and Roman mythology and represents a time that was considered untroubled and prosperous where people lived in ideal happiness. If we too are to live carefree and well off in that season of life we must plan and prepare for it. Traditionally, as Caribbean people we rely on our families and children to care for us in the retirement phase of life. In the past, many of us simply had a \"my children will mine me\" plan and most of our grandparents and even parents' generation found themselves ill prepared for a world with double digit inflation and skyrocketing food prices. We must prepare for the fact that our income from our pensions, savings and investments is now fixed and there will be no more salary increases or bonuses, while our expenses can spiral beyond our expectations. Having a fixed income with rising expenses can only lead to disaster. As individuals we cannot assume that the government or our children will mind us when we retire. No one can predict the future and the economic circumstances that may prevail. If you consider the current global economic situation, Governments across the world are trying to find ways to reduce the burden of the national pension systems on the nation's coffers. Some are cutting pension benefits while others are extending the retirement age; likewise companies are seeking ways to put the risk of pension benefits onto the member rather than have it be their obligation. A recent trend is the growing demand for defined-contribution pension plans by companies. Essentially, these plans focus on the monies invested or contributed by the employer during the period of employment and does not guarantee the level of the pension benefit to be provided upon retirement. Thus, under a defined-contribution plan you the employee will have less certainty regarding your pension income. As we mature in age the chances of our health deteriorating increases. Old age typically brings medical challenges and increased healthcare expenses. Thus, expenses which we previously didn't have to budget for now become an immediate and expensive priority. Without adequate savings, living out your Golden Years in comfort while also covering your medical expenses may become too large a burden to bear - especially if your health (or that of your loved ones) starts to deteriorate. As such, to prevent any unforeseen illness from wiping out your retirement savings, you may want to consider obtaining insurance, such as medical, critical illness and long-term care insurance, to finance any health care needs that may arise. But beyond your own needs, you have to consider your financial legacy. What will you want to leave for your children and grandchildren property an education capital to start them off in life Without a well-planned retirement nest egg, you may be forced to liquidate your assets in order to cover your own living expenses during your retirement years. This could prevent you from leaving an inheritance for your loved ones, or worse, cause you to become a financial burden on your family in your old age. The greatest challenge the future presents us with is the unknown... and it is the unforeseen illness, accident, circumstance or economy that we must also plan for when preparing for the Golden Years. There is no magic number when it comes to the amount of savings and investments that should be accumulated for retirement. But there are a few things that you should consider: 1. Decide on the age at which you want to retire 2. Estimate the annual income you'll need for your retirement years, say 80 per cent of your current annual salary in order to maintain your standard of living 3. Add up the current market value of all your savings and investments 4. Determine the effect of inflation on your savings and the return you'll need to earn to beat inflation 5. If you have a company pension plan, obtain an estimate of its value from your plan provider 6. Estimate the value of any government or national insurance benefits The most corrosive factor in planning for the future is the impact of inflation on the value of your money. Once your savings and investments earn a return below the level of inflation then the value of your money is eroding. Also, the sad irony is that the longer you live the more money you will need to have saved at retirement. Thus, start saving now!... unless of course you plan to live a short life. No one likes to think about death but it is the ultimate conclusion of life and thus we have to prepare for it financially. This article is intended to spur you into action and to reinforce the importance of you planning for the future. Seek out a trusted investment adviser and discuss your finances and future with them. Some of the likely solutions to preparing for the future will include: i) a deferred annuity that will provide you with an income stream in the future, ii) a portfolio of bonds, monthly income funds, deposits and fixed income investments that provide cash flows over a period of time, iii) dividend paying stocks that provide income, iv) investing in a property that you can rent out, v) universal life insurance that builds a cash value and that can provide for your loved ones when you transition on, and vi) home equity after years of paying a mortgage your property would have a value that can be monetised if needed or passed on to your heirs. No one knows what the future may hold but if we plan as best as we can and seek out expert advice we can ensure that the Golden Years stay golden and that we and our families will live life richly. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/flights-cancelled-loss-estimated-at-us-b/article_587474d7-8ddd-5807-b418-4363914fd3b0.html", "TITLE": " 12,000 flights cancelled, loss estimated at US$20b ", "DATE": "Oct 28, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "l atlantic city Stripped of hurricane status but every bit as dangerous, the weather monster known as Sandy wheeled toward the New Jersey and Delaware coast yesterday after washing away part of the Atlantic City boardwalk, putting the presidential campaign on hold and threatening to cripple Wall Street and the New York subway system with an epic surge of seawater. Just before it was expected to blow ashore in the evening, the National Hurricane Center announced it considered Sandy no longer a hurricane but a wintry hybrid known as a post-tropical storm. The decision was technical and based on the storm's shape and its mix of cold and warm temperaturesa distinction that meant more to meteorologists than the 50 million people still in peril. The storm's top sustained winds weakened only slightly, to 85 mph from 90. As it closed in, Sandy knocked out electricity to more than 1.5 million people and figured to upend life for tens of millions more. It smacked the boarded-up big cities of the Northeast corridor, from Washington and Baltimore to Philadelphia, New York and Boston, with stinging rain and gusts of more than 85 mph. It was expected to come ashore last night in southern New Jersey or Delaware, converging with two cold-weather systems to form a fearsome superstorm of snow, rain and wind. Forecasters warned of 20-foot waves bashing into the Chicago lakefront and up to three feet of snow in West Virginia. Airlines cancelled more than 12,000 flights, disrupting the plans of travellers all over the world, and storm damage was projected at US$10 billion to US$20 billion, meaning it could prove to be one of the costliest natural disasters in US history. At least two deaths were blamed on Sandy in the US: One person died in a storm-related traffic accident in Maryland, and a Pennsylvania man fell from a tree while trimming branches in preparation for the hurricane. US President Barack Obama and Republican challenger Mitt Romney cancelled their campaign appearances at the very height of the race, with just over a week to go before Election Day. The President pledged the government's help and made a direct plea from the White House to those in the storm's path. \"When they tell you to evacuate, you need to evacuate,\" he said. \"Don't delay, don't pause, don't question the instructions that are being given, because this is a powerful storm.\" Sandy, which killed 69 people in the Caribbean before making its way up the Atlantic, began to hook left at midday and was about 40 miles south of Atlantic City by evening, moving west-northwest at almost 30 mphfaster than forecasters expected. The storm lost its status as hurricane because it no longer had a warm core centre nor the convectionthe upward air movement in the eyethat traditional hurricanes have, but it was still as dangerous as it was when it was considered a hurricane, according to National Hurricane Center spokesman. Pete Wilson, who owns an antiques shop in Cape May, New Jersey, at the state's southern tip and directly in Sandy's path, said the water was six inches above the bottom edge of the door. He had already taken a truckload of antiques out but was certain he would take a big hit. \"My jewelry cases are going to be toast,\" he said. \"I am not too happy. I am just going to have to wait, and hopefully clean up.\" New Jersey Gov Chris Christie said people were stranded in Atlantic City, which sits on a barrier island and was mostly under water late yesterday. He accused the mayor of allowing them to stay there. With the hurricane fast approaching, Christie warned it was no longer safe for rescuers, and advised people who didn't evacuate the barrier islands to \"hunker down\" until morning. \"I hope, I pray, that there won't be any loss of life because of it,\" he said. The storm's projected path would put New York City and Long Island along its dangerous northeastern wall, facing perhaps 11 feet of water. While the hurricane's 90 mph winds registered as only a Category 1 on a scale of five, it packed \"astoundingly low\" barometric pressure, giving it terrific energy to push water inland, said Kerry Emanuel, a professor of meteorology at MIT. \"We are looking at the highest storm surges ever recorded\" in the Northeast, said Jeff Masters, meteorology director for Weather Underground, a private forecasting service. \"The energy of the storm surge is off the charts, basically.\" In New York City, authorities worried that salt water would seep through the boarded-up street grates and through the sandbags placed at subway entrances, crippling the electrical connections needed to operate the subway. Authorities also feared the surge of seawater could damage the underground electrical and communications lines in lower Manhattan that are vital to the nation's financial centre. Hours before landfall, there was graphic evidence of the storm's power. A construction crane atop a luxury high-rise in New York City collapsed in the wind and dangled precariously 74 floors above the street. Forecasters said the wind at the top the building may have been close to 95 mph. Off North Carolina, a replica of the 18th-century sailing ship HMS Bounty that was built for the 1962 Marlon Brando movie Mutiny on the Bounty went down in the storm, and 14 crew members were rescued by helicopter from rubber lifeboats bobbing in 18-foot seas. Another crew member was found hours later but was unresponsive. The captain was missing. In Maryland, at least 100 feet of a fishing pier at the beach resort of Ocean City was destroyed, and Gov Martin O'Malley said there would be devastating flooding from the swollen Chesapeake Bay. \"There will be people who die and are killed in this storm,\" he said. At least half a million people had been ordered to evacuate, including 375,000 from low-lying parts of New York City, and by the afternoon authorities were warning that it could be too late for people who had not left already. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-day-the-firetruck-crashed/article_42a82a53-ae9e-5737-8c71-55e828650999.html", "TITLE": " The day the firetruck crashed ", "DATE": "Jun 14, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "\u0091MADNESS\u0092: A resident points to the spot where the firetruck ended up after sliding off the Arima/ Blanchisseuse Road last November. \u0097Photo: DAVE PERSAD \u0091MADNESS\u0092: A resident points to the spot where the firetruck ended up after sliding off the Arima/ Blanchisseuse Road last November. \u0097Photo: DAVE PERSAD The controversial firetruck. \u0097Photo: DAVE PERSAD \u0091MADNESS\u0092: A resident points to the spot where the firetruck ended up after sliding off the Arima/ Blanchisseuse Road last November. \u0097Photo: DAVE PERSAD \u0091MADNESS\u0092: A resident points to the spot where the firetruck ended up after sliding off the Arima/ Blanchisseuse Road last November. \u0097Photo: DAVE PERSAD The controversial firetruck. \u0097Photo: DAVE PERSAD IN the early 1970s, a man from Penal and a woman from Point Fortin travelled to the United States chasing the American dream. Strangers in Trinidad, they met in Texas, married, and made a success of life. But Krishna and Rose Moonilal never forgot the homeland, and returned as often as they could, keeping ties with local family and friends. One close friend lived in the north coast village of Blanchisseuse, and the couple went visiting when they returned on vacation last November. It was on a trip back over the mountains along Trinidad's loneliest and most precipitous road, that Rose would die. She was killed in a crash that also brought out the best in the people of the village, who rescued the survivors and tried everything to keep Rose alive. However, it is also this incident that set in motion a series of unfortunate events that led to citizens having to pay $6.8 million to a private company to pull a firetruck from a ditch. The tow job done by Sammy's Multilift Services Ltd is now being described as a fiasco by Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar, and as an absurdity by people who were witness to the tow job. But first, the enduring and underrated goodness of Trinis. The Sunday Express contacted Krishna Moonilal on his cellphone last week. He was at the time driving to the home he once shared with Rose, a bank worker. Parked on the shoulder, he told his story. Moonilal said his wife, 54, was in the back seat of the car that day, sitting between relatives, as they climbed the north face of a mountain in the village of Morne La Croix, more than 25 kilometres into the Blanchisseuse/Arima Road. It was the afternoon of November 17, a Saturday. Moonilal, 62, said he pulled aside to allow a truck to squeeze by, at a spot where the road had narrowed as a result of a landslide. \"The part of the road where the left wheel was located, started to collapse, and we went down in slow motion almost,\" Moonilal recalled. The Sunday Express visited the crash site last week. The vehicle could have tumbled more than 100 metres into a valley. Instead, the car snagged on a ledge. Moonilal said: \"The vehicle went down at an angle, and stopped. Everyone in the vehicle was hurt in some way. We needed help to get out. The people of the area helped us. My wife was the last to be taken out. The residents did CPR on her. I did CPR, but we could not bring her back.\" Moonilal, who suffered minor injuries, said he was taken to the Blanchisseuse Police Station for a breathalyser test. It was negative. An autopsy later determined that Rose suffocated. Her funeral was held in Trinidad. Moonilal said he may never recover from the loss of his wife, but will be eternally grateful to the people who helped. Moonilal's luck was that the car went over at a spot across the road from a house, one of only a few for many kilometres, and at a time when much of the village was there attending a birthday party. The response was immediate. The vehicle was secured to the wall with rope to prevent it from tumbling further. The injured were removed and lifted to the road above. All except Rose, who was unresponsive, and appeared not to be breathing. She had been injured under the weight of the others in the vehicle. Morne La Croix resident Alexis Contant, 22, said she took charge. She had only just completed a course offered at the Blanchisseuse Community Centre in search and rescue and survival training. Contant, an on-the-job trainee at the Brasso Seco primary school, was on her way home when she happened upon the scene. She said: \"They taught us how to analyse situations. How to react in disaster situations. So I asked, 'Any injured How many Is the lady breathing, moving They said 'no'.\" Contant said she went down to Rose, and helped bring her out. She was wrapped in tarpaulin and brought to the roadway. \"The lady's husband. He was asking for help. I remember falling to my knees and for 15, 20 minutes performed CPR. I had to tell the mister that I was sorry, but she is gone. He started to cry. He too tried to do CPR. It was a sad day for everyone.\" Contant, and everyone else living along the road, said if the route was maintained, Rose would have been alive today. \"When it happened, there were bushes growing at that spot, no warning and no barriers. If you did not know, you could not judge that there was a drop there. They came afterwards and built a barrier.\" And it is likely for a similar reason that Fire Service Water Tender 504 slid off the Arima/Blanchisseuse Road while responding to the crash involving the Moonilals. The distress call was received by the Arima Fire Station at 6.10 p.m. of the road traffic accident. The 504, left with six firefighters aboard. According to the official fire service record, the road collapsed under the left rear wheel as the vehicle negotiated a corner, and the truck skated downhill, off the road, and overturned onto the side. Injuries were minor and all six firefighters were able to leave the vehicle and return to the roadway unaided. The report stated that the truck was 120 feet (36 metres) from the road, and a few minutes drive past the entrance to the Asa Wright Nature Centre. At 7.10 p.m, a senior fire service officer (First Division) contacted the Central Division headquarters requesting a Land, Search and Rescue (LSAR) team be contacted and deployed to the scene, to have 504 stripped of all equipment, and the water (10,000 litres) drained. The water tender, when laden, has a maximum gross weight (MGW) of 27,500 kilogrammes. The LSAR team removed the water, hoses, ladders, jaws of life device (Holmatro), breathing apparatus, tools and wireless set. The job was done by 11 a.m. the following day. The vehicle, when unladen, has a weight of 10,000 kilogrammes. The job was observed by many of the residents traveling to Arima. Not a single witness interviewed by the Sunday Express estimated the firetruck to have slid further that 60 feet (18 metres) off the road. People expected to see a tow truck used by the Public Service Transport Corporation or Ministry of Works, to arrive at the scene. Resident Robin Walker recalled a failed effort by a second firetruck to rig a winch to a tree, to get the truck out of the ravine. He was there when the truck was finally removed, and saw an excavator being used to drag the vehicle onto the roadway. \"If people came down and saw this location themselves, they would know this (claim of 300 feet) is madness,\" he said. Resident Ronnie Jadoo, who captured video footage of the firetruck in the ditch, said he saw a wrecker and excavator involved in the retrieval, equipment no different from what is used on the quarries close to where the truck went down. No one can believe the claims being made to justify the $6.8 million expenditure. Those millions could have been used to repair the road, build barriers, and save the lives of citizens, residents said. The collapsed road which caused the firetruck incident has been cordoned off with a bamboo barrier and caution tape. The wrecked fire tender is back on the compound of the Chaguanas Fire Service headquarters. Purchased at a cost of about $2 million six years ago, it will be put up for auction and sold for its metal. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/this-endangered-place/article_0884ed96-a1a0-57ff-8872-8247b7a2dede.html", "TITLE": " This endangered place ", "DATE": "Jan 12, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "We are in danger, without the politics to save ourselves. The people have never been in charge here. The alarming murder rate and the shameful inadequacy in dealing with the oil spill are symptoms of that 50-year deficiency at the heart of our country. Less than a decade into Independence, the people took to the streets calling for their power, but never got it. The 1970 eruption brought only symbolic change and the absence of the people's influence on national determination worsened over the ensuing four decades, producing a pervasive social and cultural decay, complete corruption of national life, political stagnation and levels of lawlessness and violence for which the nation has no answer in its present endangered state. The one factor which eventually saves a society, that awakened public consciousness and strong public opinion, the high politics, does not exist in T&T. It has been suffocated by a diseased tribalism. Almost half the population tolerates the corruption and incompetence of this Government; and the other half, to a lesser extent, will demand no accountability when the PNM rules the roost. The majority of people apparently love their political parties more than their children. This is the depth of corruption and irresponsibility that has led to this entire society being engulfed by the spreading swampland that I warned about two years ago. We remain a nation in name only, with no society whatsoever, an endangered place. You get alarmed when you think deeply about this country. It is now utterly leaderless, with dysfunctional institutions, a retarded constitution, antiquated governance, and an economy no longer generating the wealth to sustain our lifestyle. There is no security here. No one is in charge; the nation is a ship adrift on the high seas. Indeed our economic flagship, the energy sector, is the very symbol of national nonchalance. For 100 years we have been an oil producer but never developed the capacity to deal with industry disasters. Worse, the present oil spill is not due to accident but maintenance absent for almost 20 years, implicating both major political parties. Rusting pipelines beneath the ground serve as symbol of a country rotting beneath the surface, whilst we again get ready to trivialise ourselves with a decadent, meaningless Carnival, a country \"wining and jamming\" to the precipice. There is a clear danger to the economy, but no public to speak of it. People are lulled by business activity, consumerism and ostentation, forgetting it will all vanish like soap bubbles with the threat to our energy revenues. The Government speaks of economic growth, quoting figures that reveal stagnation but very few ask questions, including the Opposition, that epitome of intellectual laziness. There's no public to chastise their incompetence either. We were never called to responsibility for our society, never had the power that should have come with Independence, and so looseness, lethargy and mindlessness reign here, making this place easy prey for the unscrupulous and unworthy who abound in the politics of the country. Only politicians and their friends have a field day in this endangered place. After 50 years of Independence, oil and gas booms, our governance is shambolic and our major institutions disarrayed or dysfunctional. The most shameful is our Parliament through which we should have felt the people's power in national decision making. Our Parliament should have been that arena for fierce supervision of the Cabinet, for negotiation and collaboration between governors and governed like in the US congress, for example. But our house of the people has facilitated national degradation for 50 years. Instead of an instrument of the people's power, it is a place of ritual and \"grand-charge\", elementary in representation and laughable with its imitation grandeur. The Treasury is being raided every day before its eyes but it cannot protect the people's patrimony. What then is its use Why do we waste hundreds of millions of dollars every year on this impotence Did it prevent the gas station racket, Lock Joint, the Caroni Racing Complex, the Piarco Airport scandal and money laundering, the desalination plant, the Tarouba sporting complex Instead it voted unanimously three times for the treasonous Section 34. Will it do anything about the recent Auditor General's report pointing to millions of dollars wasted in the Public Service Will it investigate reports that the raiding of the Treasury is now more frenetic than ever with certain ministers now reputed billionaires from corrupt earnings All it can produce are cosmetic recommendations of a Standing Orders Committee chaired by the Speaker and leading lights from our two intellectually moribund parties. And more \"mamaguy\" is coming with the Government's proposals for constitution reform. How will term limits stop the domination of the Parliament by the Prime Minister and bring the people into the decision-making process How will a fixed date for general elections empower our parliament with the resources and authority to summon public officials to investigative committee hearings which could lead to corruption charges against public officials Will our new constitution continue to split the annual budget for national security between a police service we need to be strong and an army we never needed at all Will we at last have one strong, adequately resourced security system under one central command Isn't this country too small for an elaborate system of army, police and coast guard, each inadequate, whilst the police cannot meet the demands of modern-day law and order Our worthless political class will never summon the courage to face the tough questions of governance, security and our stagnating economy. With fourth standard politicians, ageing juveniles in Cabinet and parliament, and no power of the people, we will remain an endangered state until the implosion. \u2022 Ralph Maraj is a former government minister TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/disaster-drill-causes-gridlock/article_1c8fd997-bd39-5220-8177-3063cecbd5b2.html", "TITLE": " Disaster drill causes gridlock ", "DATE": "Jul 19, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "{{description}} Email notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items. A mid-morning disaster preparedness simulation exercise, conducted yesterday by the Tunapuna Piarco Regional Corporation (TPRC) at the Churchill Roosevelt Highway (CRH) and Macoya Road intersection, was a source of concern for motorists as it created traffic gridlock on the west-bound lanes of the highway. The exercise was undertaken in response to the call by the Office of Disaster Preparedness and Management (ODPM) for organisations to participate in its 'Exercise Turbulence 2016' initiative. The exercise, in which two of the corporation's vehicles were overturned on the roadway, began at 11 a.m. and finished at 12.15 p.m. and was fashioned to imitate a road traffic accident resulting from an 8.4 earthquake. Rishi Siew, TPRC's disaster coordinator, said: \u201cWe created an atmosphere where light poles were uprooted, trees strewn across the roadway blocking traffic and people lying on the ground suffering from injuries. \u201cWe then tested the response time of all the emergency services\u2014fire, police, Red Cross and the Global Medical Response of Trinidad and Tobago.\u201d Siew said all the emergency services responded from their bases, with none being pre-positioned, since the objective was to evaluate their real-time response. \u201cAdditionally, we had volunteers from our Disaster Management Unit play the roles of victims, with all the necessary props such as (fake) blood,\u201d Siew said. He said the exercise, which got the approval of the corporation's chairman Edwin Gooding and chief executive officer Loris Romany, was well executed and well responded to. \u201cThe drill was a tremendous success,\u201d Siew said. A similar exercise was staged simultaneously at Orange Grove Road in Tacarigua to evaluate the emergency services' capacity to deal with multiple situations. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/breaking-news/article_2b4ad249-facf-5d60-ae0e-d752826c0d28.html", "TITLE": " BREAKING NEWS ", "DATE": "Oct 15, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "We in Trinidad and Tobago pride ourselves in the strides women have made in education, in management and in leadership. We recognise and celebrate a number of feisty women who bring us the news and function as editors, commentators and hosts of various media shows in print and electronically. But here's some breaking news: the perception is one thing; the actual figures tell a story. How have our women in the media actually been impacting and changing the sphere in which they work Global Media Monitoring Day, November 10, 2009 might have been an ordinary day at work for newsroom staff. It was, however, a special day for the Network of NGOs of Trinidad and Tobago whose team monitored T&T's news media to feed into the report Who Makes the News of the Fourth Global Media Monitoring Project (GMMP). GMMP is the world's oldest and most extensive research on gender in the news media. It monitors women's voice/presence on national radio, television and print news. The GMMP exercise on that randomly chosen, fated day revealed a startling picture: 1. That presentations of women in the news had changed only marginally over the last decade; 2. That not unlike the global norm, the world that is reported in the news is mostly male; women continue to hover to near invisibility in the news; 3. Very little news just under 10% of all stories focussed specifically on women; 4. Overall, news stories were twice as likely to reinforce gender stereotypes rather than challenge them; 5. News stories on gender (in)equality were almost non-existent as in the 70-plus countries monitored; 6. Women were rarely central in stories that comprised the bulk of the news agenda. Less than 20% of news subjects the people who are interviewed or whom the news is about were women; 7. The sex of the journalist made a difference in whether or not women made the news: there were more female news subjects in stories reported by female journalists (25%) than in stories reported by male journalists (20%); 8. Expert opinion was overwhelmingly male with women comprising only 17% of experts who appeared in news stories; 9. As newsmakers, women were under-represented in professional categories. Although it may be slightly skewed in terms of representation of the general picture given its focus on one random day, the GMMP 2010 report does show that gender parity is still a somewhat distant prospect for T&T and indeed in many regions of the world. News was more often being presented by women but it was still rarely about women. On this randomly chosen day, women were outnumbered by men as newsmakers in every major news topic. In the Network's view, news media remain the major and most influential source of information, ideas and opinion for most people around the world. It is a key element of the public and private space in which people, nations and societies live. A nation or society that does not fully know itself cannot respond to its citizens' aspirations. Who and what appears in the news and how people and events are portrayed matters. Who is left out and what is not covered are equally important. Across the world, the cultural underpinnings of gender inequality and discrimination against women are reinforced through the media. Specifically, in the analyses, of media parity for women in T&T, who delivered the news in T&T On that day, 16 per cent were Women and 84 per cent were male; while the overall presence of women and men as news announcers in radio were 14 per cent female and 86 per cent male. Who are the newsmakers in Trinidad and Tobago Politicians and criminals. These two categories dominate with government officials, politicians, president, government numbering 26 stories on that day and criminal and suspect comprising ten stories. The Male to Female ratio in these two categories was 90 per cent versus 10 per cent, and 88 per cent versus 12 per cent, respectively. The presence of female and male news subjects in Trinidad and Tobago by medium radio, TV and newspapers showed Print- female subjects 24 per cent; male subjects 76 per cent. Other newsmakers were the police, military, paramilitary group, prison officers and in all instances featured men; similarly too for stories with lawyers, judges, magistrates, and legal advocate. The picture eased a little when it came to business persons, executives, managers, and entrepreneurs where women commanded some 23 per cent of the scene compared to men, at 73 per cent. In terms of gender functions assigned by/in the news, women were marginally seen as news subjects or experts/commentators (only eight per cent), and as spokespersons (only 34 per cent) with men commanding all three areas. In like manner, in construction social 'victims', in all categories victims were male subjects including areas such as accident, natural disaster, disease, poverty, domestic violence and crime. In 35 per cent of the cases, the news equated women's identity through representation of their family status, while such identity was ascribed to men in only 16 per cent of the cases. Significantly, female reporters identified men by their familial status 27 per cent of the time and women 25 per cent; while male reporters identified women 50 per cent of the time in this way and men only 9 per cent. Also significantly, female sources were equally sought by male and female reporters (50/50). However male sources were sought more by female reporters than male reporters (59/41). In effect, it also showed that female reporters reinforced gender stereotypes 100 per cent of the time and male reporters 94 per cent. This disparity however only represents one story in which the male reporter neither challenged nor reinforced stereotypes. Overall, the Network found that 'Politics and Government' was one of the most highly discussed topics and also represented one of the highest percentage differences between male and female reporters 74 per cent versus 26 per cent respectively. The gender gap was also strongly felt in topic ranked third 'Social and Legal' with 83 per cent versus 17 per cent and in 'Celebrity, Arts and Media' with 79 per cent versus 21 per cent male to women. 'Crime and Violence', however presented an almost equal figure of 51 per cent versus 49 per cent and women led only in two lower-ranking categories of Economy and Science and Health by small margins. Not unexpectedly, the overall presence of women was highest in relation to the least popular topic 'Celebrity, Arts and the Media' (64 per cent), while the two highest ranking topics 'Politics & Government' and 'Crime & Violence' presented the greatest disparities of men to women, with 93 per cent versus seven per cent; and 95 per cent versus five per cent respectively. Female subjects were present 100 per cent of the time in the following topics: Women's movement, activism, events, demonstrations, gender equality and advocacy, beauty contests, models, fashion, beauty aids, cosmetic surgery, and Celebrities, Arts and Media. Other high female representation showed 50-60 per cent representation in reporting related to: Education, child care, nursery, pre schools to University, adult education, literacy; Economic policies, strategies, models; Medicine, health, hygiene, safety, disabilities, medical research, funding and 'other' (minor) stories on politics and government. There was a male subject in 100 per cent of the time in 20 out of 50 topics and an overall percentage of 85. Some of the statistics are in the chart below. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/a-place-for-t-t-in-japan-s-future/article_6622aa91-f607-5f22-aefc-0542799b54a2.html", "TITLE": " A place for T&T in japan's future ", "DATE": "Feb 27, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "locked doors: Pedestrians walk past the Catwalk store on Independence Square in Port of Spain yesterday. \u0097Photo: AYANNA KINSALE Koichi Shiraga, centre, director at the Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency. \u0097Photos: Ria Taitt locked doors: Pedestrians walk past the Catwalk store on Independence Square in Port of Spain yesterday. \u0097Photo: AYANNA KINSALE Koichi Shiraga, centre, director at the Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency. \u0097Photos: Ria Taitt The Ministry of Foreign Affairs building, located in Tokyo, Japan is cold. It seems almost as cold as outside, as we settle down for our interview with Noriyuki Shikata, director of global communications at Japan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs. But the public servants are not complaining about the temperature of the building. They casually explain to us that the government is leading the way in conserving energy. Everywhere there is evidence that the country is serious about this goal. The water in the taps in the rest-rooms at the restaurants and other public places is ice cold. And when we took a taxi the driver switched off the engine every time the traffic forced him to come to a stop. Japan is conducting a major review of its energy policy in which the saving of energy is one plank. Trinidad and Tobago with its heavy investment in liquefied natural gas would be happy to know that LNG is likely to emerge a major source of energy in this review. \"The proportion of LNG will increase...In terms of power generation, LNG is playing a bigger role,\" Shikata said. The accident at the Fukushima nuclear plant in Japan which came in the wake of the March 2011 earthquake and tsunami and the attendant threat it posed to the people, has turned the population away from nuclear energy and has sparked a nationwide debate about Japan's energy policy. With 99 per cent of its oil coming from imports, Japan had pursued a policy of diversification away from oil and into nuclear energy for its energy requirement with a goal of achieving 50 per cent of its energy from nuclear power by 2030. And it was getting there. By March 2011, 30 per cent of its power generation was coming from domestic nuclear power plants. Now of the 54 nuclear reactors in the country, only five are operating, significantly reducing the country's reliance on nuclear energy from 30 per cent to three per cent. In the face of popular concerns and opposition to continued reliance on nuclear energy for its power supplies, the government is conducting stress tests at all the power plants. But there is a strong feeling that the nuclear reactors should be decommissioned. Shikata noted that under the current situation, given public opinion, it would be difficult to construct any new nuclear plants. \"But the government is hoping to see if it is possible to resume the existing operations at the current nuclear plants. But that is an ongoing issue,\" he stressed. If those 51 reactors (currently not operational) are not back up by the end of April, there will probably be no nuclear plants operating in Japan, he predicted. The new draft energy policy comes out for public comment in the summer. \"You are talking about losing 30 per cent of your power generation. The government is coming up with ways to address this. There is a resumption of coal and we are importing more gas, in the form of LNG. Compared to coal however, gas is cleaner and therefore there is a preference in Japan for gas,\" Shikata said. LNG now accounts for over 50 per cent of Japan's energy supply. The Japanese government has faced criticism that its cost assessment for nuclear power was underestimated. Nuclear energy was originally attractive because it was cheaper. \"But now there is a re-evaluation of the cost assessment if one has to take into account the cost for safety measures and extra requirements to guarantee 100 per cent safety. It adds up,\" Shikata said. He explained that Japan's nuclear power policy came after the oil shocks of 1973 and 1979 when Japan's economy was growing rapidly and there were fears that high oil prices could cause it to collapse. Then Japanese companies, like Toyota, responded to the challenge by producing more fuel efficient automobiles and these companies invested so heavily in energy efficiency that they became competitive globally. In fact Japan became the world's leading energy-conserving nation in the aftermath of the oil shocks. The Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda said on January 24 that the country faces the same challenge now in the wake of the Great East Japan Earthquake. \"The challenge is not to bring back the old Japan but to create a new Japan,\" he said. Japan gets its LNG from Qatar, Indonesia, Malaysia and Australia. On the possibility of importing from Caribbean and Latin American countries, Shikata said Japan needed to invest in countries like Trinidad and Tobago. He recalled that in the 1970s when it wanted to diversify its energy sources, Japan thought about importing oil from Mexico and Venezuela. \"But the reality of the global energy supply and demand is that there is a stronger pull from the US. So it seems easier for Latin America and the Caribbean exports to go to the US,\" Shikata said. The goals of Japan's new energy policy are lower dependence on nuclear energy power, more saving of energy and more use of renewable energy such as solar, wind, and geothermal energy. Nine per cent of Japan's energy comes from renewable sources, with hydroelectric power being the dominant source. The government has given incentives to companies using renewable energy. Many of the nuclear reactors in Japan are located near the sea, because seawater is used in their cooling systems. Because of the huge tsunami last March, reactors at Yukushima which face the Pacific Ocean were affected when 14-15-metre tsunami waves hit the emergency diesel generators, flooding and crippling them, leading to a hydrogen explosion and the leakage of nuclear material into the environment into the atmosphere and the sea. There were two major leakages into the ocean on April 2 and May 11 when, in an effort to cool down the reactors, fire engines were deployed to spray water and cracks in the building which allowed contaminated water to leak into the sea. The contaminated water was found inside the port area and according to Koichi Shiraga, director at the Nuclear and Industrial Safety Agency, these levels have been decreasing steadily. A water-shielding steel wall has been installed at the plant to prevent any more contaminated water from leaking out into the sea. This is being done at nuclear power stations all over the country as one of the lessons of this disaster is that there should be sea walls to prevent tsunamis from flooding the nuclear power plant site. The other lesson is ensuring that there are external power supplies. Next week: How the nuclear disaster has changed Japan's relations with the world. Ria Taitt visited Japan from January 27 to February 7 at the invitation of the Japanese Government. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/the-way-we-were/article_ad103113-2b8a-596b-9a57-838de3df3e50.html", "TITLE": " The way we were ", "DATE": "Nov 2, 2013 ", "CONTENT": " I do not think that its just my imagination. I am thinking that this was a better country in which to live in the era of my youth, going back to my earliest recollections in the 1950s. But how could that be, what with readily observable affluence everywhere now Big houses, expensive vehicles, everyone with cellphones, trips abroad. There is certainly greater access now to education, to basic amenities such as water, electricity, and roads. We have embraced the information age. Whatever device is brought to the market today in a major metropolitan centre, we will have available here and on sale by morning. No, I do not doubt that on many objective measures we have come a long way. Yes, we are living longer now. But we are more jittery. We are afraid of shadows, for good reason. The galleries in houses are not used anymore. In the old days people sat in their galleries and watched others go by on the street. Or they looked out of windows. These were commonplaces. Now houses are fortresses. Burglar proofing is standard and is now an industry. People are locked inside once darkness appears. In the old days boys had childhoods. Pre-teen and teenaged boys in Marabella engaged in all of the seasonal cultural games. Top spinning, marble pitching, and kite flying. These were all communal games. During the summer vacation, we made slingshots. In cricket season we played gozeen. Young men in villages everywhere in this country ran foot races against each other, lamp-post to lamp-post, seeking bragging rights. In Port of Spain boys converged on the savannah, from everywhereBelmont, Gonzales, Harpe Place, and from up the hillto fly kite, or play football. Childhood and adolescence are stages we must all pass through. Many Afro-Trinidadian boys are not passing through these stages. They are being force-riped into manhood and into criminality. In his first week in secondary school, my young relative was accosted by Form Two boys who were trying to tax him. This is practice for a later date when they do the same to anyone who wants to come into their territory with a taxi, or who wants to open a little parlour. So boys are practising extortion in Form Two. In my youth the deaths that were reported most frequently in the newspapers were those caused by road accidents. Today they are due to murders. We saw a teenaged boy being held in protective custody recently. Wearing a mask he led the police to a grave in the woods. Young boys are defending streets and alleys with their lives. Boys who should be playing small goal and trying to get O-Levels. Or who should be in a technical school, learning how to design video-games, or how to make computers. But they stand as sentinels throughout the night watching for intruders from other streets. Where are the fathers or the step-fathers or uncles At 15 you should have to answer to somebody at home that you fear. And the women come to their limit as custodians of discipline when boys start trying to prove manhood on the block. Our country is now a world leader in crime. Ahead of big powers like Japan and the United States. In 2012 the number of murders committed in Japan was 506. This is for a population of 127 million people. This yields a murder rate of 0.4 per 100,000 people. The US state with the highest murder rate is Louisiana. In 2012, its murder rate was 10.8 per 100,000. The number of murders in Trinidad and Tobago for 2012 was 379 for a population of 1.3 million people. This yields a murder rate of 29.1 per 100,000 people. How did this once idyllic country get to become one of the most deadly places on the planet How could we be ahead of the United States and Japan in the rate of murders We certainly cannot blame politicians for that. I think we have to blame ourselves as a collective. Why have we gone so far in our callousness towards our fellow man Why are our youth, especially black youth, so uncaring about their brothers Why is the threshold for taking a life in this society so low We lost our way on the road to development. But why did the Japanese not lose their way Our society is adrift, and the reason is that we do not have a centre, a place to turn back to collectively, where we can recalibrate, and thus rejuvenated, start afresh. I am not talking about religion. I am talking about values. Our loss of the value of simpleness. Our loss of a rallying point. In times past neighbours would keep an eye on children so someone could go to the market. Children would play ring games on moonlight nights under the supervision of adults. Neighbours would bake bread collectively. But now we have lost or forgotten all of the foundations of the moral economy we once had. This is an economy that was founded on neighbourliness, trust, sharing, respect for elders. In that economy, children were children and adults were adults. Children knew their boundaries in dealing with adults. They knew how to address adults, and how to act in their presence. They knew that adults would tell on them if they saw wrongdoing. Grown men acted grown and thus commanded respect. Men who never went to school themselves provided encouragement to you as a boy, that you should go to school. A few days ago I heard on the BBC that tens of thousands of people in Japan are still residing in camps or other shelters far from their homes, ordered to do so when the tsunami struck the country in 2011, and the nuclear plant was breached. What we have not heard from Japan is that there is unrest among those who have not been able to go to their homes after this long. On that fateful day in 2011 the country suffered the triple whammy of a magnitude 9 earthquake, followed by a tsunami that killed 21,000 people, followed by a nuclear meltdown. The country as a whole reacted with stoicism. Japan has a moral centre, a place to which it can go in times such as national disaster. It has tradition and a culture of orderliness to turn to. I think that if we go back in history in this country, we will come to a time when there was civic harmony, when people shared sugar and flour, and when the watchful eyes of every adult were on a child playing in the street. We could look to Tobago for a glimpse of what the country used to be. We would see the power of simplicity. People respecting each other, strong family bonds, strong village bonds, fishermen helping each other, elders being revered, children being children and knowing their place. I think at some point when the country turned the corner materially, we failed to look back to see what we were leaving behind. It was not just the old-time Morris chair we threw out, or the old latrine that we pushed down. When petro dollars took hold we also threw away the moral/ethical software on which the country ran in the times when we were poor. We lost patience, honesty, and the work ethic. We lost values, such as honesty and integrity. We have to get back to the way we were. We are just an island where a bicycle sometimes makes more sense that a Ferrari. We have to get back to simpleness. Theodore Lewis, emeritus professor, University of Minnesota. * Michael Harris returns next week. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/an-accident-waiting-to-happen/article_1563fea7-b59e-522d-a890-6b12db823f0f.html", "TITLE": " An accident waiting to happen ", "DATE": "Mar 30, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "On a fateful December day when Christmas shopping occupied the minds of most people, a 16-inch diameter sea line broke at the State-owned Petrotrin refinery, sending a rush of black fuel oil into the Gulf of Paria and along the south-western coastline. The effect of that spill is still being felt today by fisher folk and people in poor coastal communities. The Express takes a close look at the chain of events that led to this country's worst environmental disaster. This is the second in a series of articles by Camini Marajh, head, Express Investigative Desk: Sea line No 10, the 40-plus-year-old fuel oil line that ruptured on an early December morning, was an accident waiting to happen. In addition to the severe external corrosion problems already identified, No 10 had five inoperable and leaking expansion joints, one missing in action altogether, leaking valves and flanges, segments of bare metal exposed, severely worn and loose safety wrappings, severely corroded chain and channel supports, cracks on support bolts and 41 identified areas where the channel beam support, including bearing plates and pile caps, were found to be severely corroded and perforated. Inspection Advice Ticket (IAT) 763/2013 which was issued on December 27, 11 days after the rupture on No. 10, found a range of safety hazards, including cracks on bolting hardware associated with the expansion joints, leaking gaskets and metal loss of between two to three millimeters. The inspection ticket laid bare some of the more vulnerable parts of Petrotrin's most famous sea line, which successive management and boards of directors at Petrotrin ignored, allowing No 10 to continue its business of transporting hazardous product as usual, that is, until December 17, when the line finally gave way. Petrotrin's own reports reveal that the company intentionally and knowingly failed to comply with industry safety standards. And as reported yesterday, its lead investigator on the December 17 incident, Mervyn Cummings, found that the refinery failed to follow its own mechanical integrity management plan. The architect of the plan, Gamini Hapuarachchi, Petrotrin's former head of Inspection Engineering, was clear that the ten-year inspection programme, if followed, would keep the refinery's marine infrastructure safe. The Hapuarachchi Plan He put it this way in his report: \"The ten-year sea line inspection programme was generated utilising the mechanical integrity report. This programme displays the inspection schedule for each sea line based on its risk ranking, location and service and inspection frequency.\" Noting that the sea lines were exposed to a marine environment, Hapuarachchi said: \"The corrosiveness of each line varies with the degree of exposure. Subsea lines are classified into two sections, above water as well as riser piping. Special care needs to be addressed to riser piping in the splash zone areas. \"These lines are exposed to a high degree of turbulence, thereby making them susceptible to an increased rate of erosion corrosion. These riser piping are rated as high risk lines and are assigned inspection intervals of two years. Recommendations are made to apply the required coatings or wrappings on these lines so as to maintain their integrity. \"The environmental impact played an important factor in the risk ranking of the lines due to the consequences of an oil spill and its effect on the environment and sea life. Samples were taken from failed sections of sea lines in various services. On inspections of these failed samples it was noted that the failure of the lines were primarily due to external corrosion. Internal corrosion of these lines were found to be negligible when compared to that of the external.\" The 2010 Hapuarachchi plan said: \"A risk assessment was carried out on each sea line where each line was ranked based on their probability and consequence of failure. The risk assigned to each line is based on the Risk Assessment Matrix implemented within Petrotrin. This classification is done for high, medium and low ratings for the sea lines, where high risk requires a two-year inspection frequency and medium and low requires a four to six and a six to ten-year frequency, respectively.\" \"A major factor that was taken into consideration in the determination of the consequences of failure is that of the availability of spare lines. Much emphasis is paid on the effect of assets and environment, if a failure should occur. It is assumed that the mode of failure of these lines being that of a corrosion hole.\" The only trouble with the Hapuarachchi plan is Petrotrin's failure to implement. \u2014To be continued on Sunday TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/funeral-drama/article_0b382357-f3b7-5adf-8107-82a1dc6fbf19.html", "TITLE": " FUNERAL DRAMA ", "DATE": "Jan 7, 2009 ", "CONTENT": "Stuck in traffic in Doha: Cars and vans came to a complete standstill, all trying to get onto Al Corniche for the country's National Day fireworks display. \u0097Photo: renuka singh Stuck in traffic in Doha: Cars and vans came to a complete standstill, all trying to get onto Al Corniche for the country's National Day fireworks display. \u0097Photo: renuka singh THEY were not letting their heroine leave just like that. No way. So villagers of Siparia, who did not attend the funeral service for fallen boxing hero Jizelle Salandy at the St Benedict's Roman Catholic Church, La Romaine, yesterday, converged on the hearse as it arrived at the Siparia Public Cemetery and demanded that the coffin be opened. Not even the police were able to control the hundreds who waited in the blazing sun, some taking up vantage positions, to say farewell to their daughter of the soil. Several attempts were made to have the pathway cleared for the hearse to pass but the shouts for the coffin to be opened grew even louder. Unable to go further, the decision was made to give the mourners an opportunity to view Salandy's body. Caution tape, placed earlier by the police, was torn down and a mad dash was made towards the coffin. Police moved in, in an attempt to bring some order to the madness. At the graveside, where her mother was also laid to rest, Salandy's family and friends held on to each other and wailed openly while final rites, by members of a Baptist church, were being performed. Hundreds also turned up at the church in La Romaine to pay their respects to Salandy who succumbed to injuries suffered when the car she was driving crashed on the Beetham Highway, Port of Spain on Sunday. Former national U-20 footballer Tamar Watson, who was with Salandy in the car, remained a patient at the Port of Spain General Hospital, where she is being treated for several broken bones. The parade of dignitaries at the funeral service included President George Maxwell Richards and his wife Dr Jean Ramjohn-Richards, Sports Minister Gary Hunt, Culture Minister Marlene McDonald, San Fernando West Member of Parliament Junia Regrello, San Fernando Mayor Kenneth Ferguson, Legal Affairs Minister Peter Taylor; Opposition MPs Jack Warner and Winston Peters; Ambassador Joan Yuille-Williams and double Olympic silver medallist Richard Thompson. Thompson and fellow Olympic sprinter Monique Cabral were also involved in an early morning accident on New Year's Day, moments after leaving the 51 Degrees nightclub and lounge on Cipriani Boulevard, Port of Spain. Also present were Salandy's promoter, Boxu Potts, her manager Harry Ragoonanan and his wife, Senior Magistrate Lucina Cardenas-Ragoonanan, and calypsonian SuperBlue. Salandy, a Chaconia Gold Medal recipient, who would have turned 22 on January 25, was decked out in a boxing robe and a pair of red, white and black boxing gloves. In his eulogy, Fr David Khan said Salandy's death should not be looked at as a disaster but as the work of God. \"Jizelle left this world as the greatest world champion, so let not your heart be troubled,\" Khan said. His words seemed to bring little comfort to the bereaved. \"Imagine she left this world as the greatest world champion. That is how she will go down in history and God took her at that point. God took her after her last success. \"We have heard from so many (who have said) that they love Jizelle. I say to all of you who said you love Jizelle, you are to become, not as good as her, but better. \"The people of this nation, if we really loved this young woman, we should even excel beyond her so we can say 'I am the person I am today because of Jizelle 'Magic' Salandy'.\" Saying his words might be viewed as a sore point, Khan said every driver knew how dangerous it was to speed on the road but some just would not learn. \"It is a point which should hit home in our hearts. We know the things that are dangerous for us.\" Potts, who delivered the eulogy, said Salandy would go down in history as the most decorated boxer of all time and praised her humble nature. Hunt also addressed the congregation saying God chose the sport of boxing as an avenue for Salandy to serve her country. \"Jizelle won the hearts and minds of many citizens by the way she conducted herself in and out of the ring,\" Hunt said.
