{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/petrotrin-ignored-warnings-about-leaky-pipeline/article_ad699ad0-3eac-5f94-8de5-95651e39329b.html", "TITLE": " Petrotrin ignored warnings about leaky pipeline ", "DATE": "Mar 29, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Offshore: Section of Petrotrin\u0092s marine facility with its network of pipelines, the main transfer hub for the refinery\u0092s petroleum products like crude, fuel oil, gasoline, aviation fuel and kerosene. crucial document: The Hapuarachchi ten-year sea line mechanical integrity report. Note the scheduled 2010 appointment for inspection tests for No.10 sea line which was not done. Offshore: Section of Petrotrin\u0092s marine facility with its network of pipelines, the main transfer hub for the refinery\u0092s petroleum products like crude, fuel oil, gasoline, aviation fuel and kerosene. crucial document: The Hapuarachchi ten-year sea line mechanical integrity report. Note the scheduled 2010 appointment for inspection tests for No.10 sea line which was not done. On a fateful December day when Christmas shopping occupied the minds of most people, a 16-inch diameter sea line broke at the State-owned refinery, sending a rush of black fuel oil into the Gulf of Paria and along the south western coastline. The effect of that spill is still being felt today by fisherfolk and people in poor coastal communities. The Express takes a close look at the chain of events that led to this countrys worst environmental disaster in history. This is the first in a series of articles by Camini Marajh, head, Express Investigative Desk: FOR over a decade, State oil and gas giant Petrotrin ignored multiple leaks in its fuel transmission pipelines, safety warnings and its own recommendations to repair and replace aged and severely corroded infrastructure, including sea line No. 10, which ruptured last December 17 sending an estimated 7,453 barrels of fuel oil into the Gulf of Paria and coastal communities along the south western peninsula. In its push for increased production and bigger profit margins, Petrotrin rolled the dice in a high-stakes gamble which saw warnings go unheeded, essential maintenance pushed back and corners cut as it outsourced more of its work to private contractors with little or - in the case of No. 10 sea line - no attention paid to safety standards and industry best practices, Express investigations have found. From all accounts, including its own inspection records, audit reports, interviews with current and former officials, and other internal company data, Petrotrin knew about the potential and existing hazards identified with the continued use of poorly maintained and aged transmission pipelines. CARELESS ACTIONS The States biggest money spinner (liable for an annual $5 billion in petroleum taxes) had full knowledge that some of its marine assets did not meet strict industry fitness for service standards, yet continued, some say recklessly and dangerously, to push the safety envelope by using corroded, high-risk and leaky pipelines to move hazardous product. The evidence on record shows that the December 17 oil spill disaster could have been averted had the company paid attention to the long laundry list of inspection recommendations made by its own safety experts, including the phased change-out of the 1,875 kilometre-long No.10 sea line. Successive management top brass and boards of directors in the State oil and gas company failed to act on any of the several inspection reports related to No. 10 sea line, including a 1996 report which recommended a phased change-out of the severely corroded 40-plus-year-old sea line. Classified High Risk The failed line was issued an E3E ranking in an October 2010 diagnostic by then-head of Petrotrins Inspection Engineering department, Gamini Hapuarachchi, in a bid to overhaul key parts of the companys mechanical integrity management plan. The E3E classification is deemed high risk on the companys integrity evaluation Risk Assessment Matrix (RAM), which means it is almost certain to leak. It is also the third highest possible risk contemplated in the Petrotrin RAM and carries a bucket list of potential hazards in the event of a spill, including negative publicity and damage to the companys image, health and environmental issues and a $5 million hit in the pocket. Delayed Maintenance Petrotrins own records show that the company pushed back two crucial inspections in the years leading up to the rupture of the 16-inch, carbon-steel, above-water No. 10 sea line which the Hapuarachchi inspection report found had severe external corrosion. The line was scheduled to undergo visual inspection (VI) and ultrasonic thickness (UT-STD) tests in 2010 and a line inspection in 2011, according to Inspection Report 016-2010, the Hapuarachchi blueprint for keeping the refinery safe. Documents obtained by this newspaper reveal that the company, which posted a $2.5 billion profit in 2011, continued to play cheap with critical equipment maintenance schedules and spend big on experimental projects and plant upgrades. It shaded the truth and used selective data to present a skewed picture of efficiency and aggressive maintenance management. Worst Environmental disaster on record Company bosses read from the same script as they sought to deflect responsibility for what has been described as the worst environmental disaster in this countrys history. It denied union accusations that it failed to implement high priority schedule of works and countered that it adhered to industry best practice, namely the American Petroleum Institute (API) 570 standard. But did they In statements made to the media and full-page advertisements, the company held that it completed several inspections on No.10 sea line since 2006 and as recently as 2011. But its own internal investigation report into the December 17 incident shows that to be untrue The Petrotrin report, which reviewed historical company inspection data, found only three reports related to No.10, specifically: Inspection Advice Report No.0515 of 1996 (recommendation for phased change-out of sea line still to be implemented) Inspection Advice Ticket NTA 103/2006 (an advice ticket is not considered a complete inspection report and does not reflect work undertaken, if done at all) Inspection report 016-2010 (the Hapuarachchi report which examined all 40 sea lines at the Point-a-Pierre refinery, including No.10. The inspection recommendations contained in this report were not adhered to). The accident report failed to address the two scheduled inspections recommended for No. 10 in the 2010 report and made only a vague reference to the planned roll out of new two year inspection intervals recommended for identified high risk lines. No. 10 was among five high risk lines flagged by Hapuarachchi for urgent attention within a prescribed two-year period. Crucial Inspections Skipped The internal probe, which Petrotrin has kept under wraps since late January, said this about the Hapuarachchi plan to improve plant safety: Several sea lines should be inspected as per a given schedule, including No.10 sea line to be done by 2011. It said further that most of the sea lines, including No.10 should be replaced on a phased basis. The report by the four-member Petrotrin team, headed by process engineer Mervyn Cummings, made passing mention of Petrotrins failure to implement its own risk assessment process. It said this: Based on the data gathered, gaps were identified in the maintenance effort, asset integrity monitoring and the understanding and implementation of procedures. It was concluded that the failure of pipe supports for No.10 sea line expansion joint at Pile Bent 122 on the main viaduct led eventually to failure during the loading of the barge Marabella. Elements of planned preventative maintenance were in place but the implementation questionable. Failure to Meet API Standards The report fails to identify the gaps in question or why there were gaps at all given the 016-2010 Hapuarachchi blueprint which was copied to a roster of 17 managers including vice president, Refining and Marketing (R&M) Mado Bachan and senior manager of Refining Luke McSween. An electronic copy of the report and its attachments were also posted on the companys web. The Cummings report, however, admits in a roundabout way to Petrotrins failure to comply with API industry standards. It puts it this way: It was also concluded that the engineering support required to guide the process was either not engaged or not available. The report does not examine why this was so. Publicly, Petrotrin went on the offensive with tales of sabotage conspiracy and employee negligence. The company was quick to rule out safety lapses or willful neglect of pipeline assets it knew were on borrowed time as it defended itself against repeated claims of negligence and calls for an independent investigation by the bargaining union representing workers, the Oilfields Workers Trade Union (OWTU), fisherfolk, coastal communities harmed by the oil spill and other stakeholders. Company Lies It attempted to counter-punch union boss Ancel Rogets outspoken criticism of Petrotrin and his charge of negligence with a defence that the company operated a robust asset integrity management system and complied with API standards. But the companys own documents show this to be untrue. Petrotrins top brass Lindsay Gillette and Khalid Hassanali asserted that, contrary to Rogets claims, sections of No.10 sea line had been changed out in the last 24 months in compliance with industry standards. Public statements, advertisements and e-mail responses to questions from this reporter all maintained that any statement suggesting that there has been no inspection and/or maintenance performed on this line is incorrect. Official company statements identified the API 570 piping inspection code as the standard Petrotrin followed. Flawed Defence It went further, pointing out that the API inspection code recommends maximum inspection intervals for the various classes of piping systems, namely Class 1: 5 years and Class 3: 10 years. According to Petrotrin, No.10 sea line, falls within the Class 3 range. The company noted that: In keeping with the recommendations of the inspection programme, critical parts of sea line No.10 have been changed and work is ongoing. This defence is completely at odds with the Hapuarachchi ten-year inspection plan which used factors like age, historical data and corrosive condition of the line. Also, the API 570 classification for inspections is based on the premise of new and/or rehabilitated pipeline, not severely corroded and leaky 40- plus-year-old sea line. Hassanali, Petrotrins president, in an e-mailed response to the Express on what sections of No.10 have been changed out since the initial 1996 inspection report, said: Repairs have been carried out over the years in accordance with recommendations and most recently in 2013 approximately 200 ft of pipeline was changed. He did not respond to questions on whether the repairs were certified or whether it sufficiently addressed the severe corrosion issues identified in the 016-2010 report. Work on No.10 not Certified It also appears that he did not share this information with the team he appointed to probe the failed No.10 sea line. The Cummings report talks of a recent change-out (prior to the December failure) of 120 ft of pipeline on No.10 and apparent quality control lapses in supervising this pipe replacement job which was done in close proximity to the ruptured expansion joint. He made bare-bones mention of work done without inspection and/or mechanical and civil engineering input. According to him: This was evident based on the fact that there was no engineering input into the replacement of circa 120 ft of No.10 sea line that took place within the last few months. The line was replaced because of a leak, which was at first clamped, then the opportunity taken to install replacement pipe between two existing flanges. Cummings noted that: This replacement began at Pile Bent (PB) 124, which was close to PB 122, where the expansion joint failed. Pointing to the detailed planned preventive maintenance (PPM) blueprint developed by Hapuarachchi, he said: It appears that there is a lack of coherency and effectiveness regarding the implementation of the PPM program. He pointed to the high incidence of leaking glands in the fuel oil pumps in No.1 Pump house as further evidence that the PPM is not functioning as designed. Given his findings, it may not surprise him that it was actually 240 ft of pipe that was changed out on No.10. Also, there is no inspection documentation or mechanical completion certificates or any quality assurance/control documentation or individual inspection report that No.10 sea line was partially renewed before it dramatically gave way on that fateful December day - clear violations of the API 570 code. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/accident-paralyses-country/article_4f287a52-933d-58bf-bfab-d4f1bd9b6e97.html", "TITLE": " Accident paralyses country ", "DATE": "Jun 17, 2011 ", "CONTENT": " I WAS seething with anger last week Tuesdayand I was not even among the tens of thousands of commuters trapped in horrendous traffic jams that paralysed around 25 per cent of Trinidad. One fuel tank wagon overturns close to the Gasparillo/ Petrotrin flyover on the Hochoy Highway and commuters from as far north as the CR Highway intersection, through all of central-south Trinidad, steam in their stalled or slow-moving vehicles for up to seven hours. And we lay claim to being on the brink of developed country status Give me a break! I was not in the traffic, but I first observed its deleterious effects when I took my ritual late-afternoon walk. The street on which I exercise runs off the Cedar Hill Road, Claxton Bay, not far from the Southern Main Road (SMR) Junction. When I got to the intersection, I saw the west-bound lane jammed with vehicles. They hardly moved. I had heard of the noon accident on the news, which also spoke of heavy traffic on the Hochoy and Butler highways, and advised motorists to use alternative routes. But I never imagined that at 5 p.m. people would be still stewing every-which-by-way, not to add being at a standstill on the highways. As I walked, I peered in both directions, looking for police officers. Not a uniform in sight. I hear sirens, presumably from ambulances trying to force they way through the logjams, to take patients for medical attention. Earlier, I had received phone calls from friends and relatives who were stuck in the mess and asking about alternative routes. I offered what advice I could, but it hardly helped. Later, on television news, when I saw images of Disaster Day, I was livid. Traffic was at a standstill, or barely moving, from as far north as the CR intersection. Trinidad had suffered a major stroke: its main artery was severed. From other reports, all ancillary roads, including the alternative SMR, were similarly stricken. Some wise fools (an oxymoron, I know!) decided to abruptly stop traffic in both directions as close as 150 metres to the overturned tank wagon. Had that tanker exploded, scores or people closest to it would have been blown to shreds or burnt to death. I am sure, too, infirm persons trapped in the jam must have suffered, maybe even died later, as a consequence of the torture they had undergone. Instead of a disaster plan, what the authorities inflicted on us was an unplanned disaster. What irks me most is that there were options available to mitigate the mess. In a situation like that, given where the accident happened, the Gasparillo and San Fernando police, as well as officers from nearby Petrotrin's security, should have been first on the scene. Fire officials from Petrotrin and San Fernando would be next: they focus on averting an explosion, which, in this instance, they did. Recognising the magnitude of the challenge, the senior police officer in the accident zone alerts the Police Commissioner who directs a senior officer to quickly evaluate the problem using a helicopter from the Air Guard of the Defence Force. While aboard, he notes the extent of the highway jam, and orders divisional chiefs to mobilise manpower to divert traffic from the highways onto alternative roads. He sees the feeder roads, as well as the SMR, similarly clogged. Clearly, there is need for maximum police personnel to keep traffic moving along these roads. The two new Augusta Westland helicopters move into action, collecting police officers and maybe soldiers in Port of Spain or Chaguaramas or San Fernando. The helicopters make several trips, and within two hours, officers are strategically deployed at key points on the highways, the feeder roads and most of all on the SMR. The helicopters use playfields nearest the \"trouble spots\" (mainly junctions) to drop off officers. They run to their nearby posts and immediately regulate traffic. This task is no high scienceI have seen civilians do it at accident spots. On the SMR, a major challenge is maxi-taxis that insist on stopping in the middle of the road to drop off or pick up passengers. If they insist on being boorish in the midst of a crisis, park them aside for the day! Traffic wardens should litter districts like Marabella, the San Fernando By-Pass, and similar alternative routes, again, keeping traffic moving. No parking is allowed on any of these clogged roads. So on the ground you have a few hundred officers dealing with a crisis situation, and in the air, helicopters patrol the clogged arteries hailing offenders (parked vehicles, for example), ordering them to get moving or get off the roads. Assuming such mobilisation got underway one hour after the mishap (1 p.m.), by 3 p.m. the sections of the highway closest (Claxton Bay to Tarouba) would have been clear of all vehicles, even if that meant having them drive in the wrong direction, to get them out of harm's way. With adequate officers policing the \"escape\" routes, traffic will have flowed, albeit at a slow pace. But such plan will have allowed for the disabled tanker to be made safe and removed from the highway by 3 p.m., restoring the free flow of traffic. There is much more I can write about handling such crises with military precision. However, if the best solution Minister Jack Warner can come up with is a ban on heavy trucks from the nation's roadways during daytime, what can a sober citizen say Go, Boyo, go!! {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/bangladesh-single-moms-want-jobs-better-lives/article_82d4e288-7f17-5d32-972b-eb7c5ea74b73.html", "TITLE": " Bangladesh single moms want jobs, better lives ", "DATE": "Mar 23, 2012 ", "CONTENT": " broken promises: Jaggernauth Mahabir, 66, says he does not feel MP Herbert Volney has kept the promises made during the 2010 election period. broken promises: Jaggernauth Mahabir, 66, says he does not feel MP Herbert Volney has kept the promises made during the 2010 election period. It is difficult to find support for St Joseph MP Justice Minister Herbert Volney in his St Joseph constituency. In the community of Bangladesh, in Farm Road, St Joseph, the Sunday Express could not find support for the representative who took over from the People's National Movement's (PNM) Kennedy Swaratsingh after the May 24, 2010 general election. A squatting community from its start, the \"village\" is in stark contrast to most of the constituency which, though still quaint in places, is obviously better off financially than the residents of Bangladesh. Most of the homes are in disrepair, with quite a few clearly constructed from cast-off materials. On one empty \"lot\", a pile of wooden shipping pallets were waiting to be taken apart and used to build and repair. Most of the members of that community who spoke last week were single mothers. They want jobs, they said, and better living conditions for their children. Many of them said they are not interested in working with the Community-based Environmental Protection and Enhancement Programmme (CEPEP). \"We can't mind our children on CEPEP,\" said Isha Ali, who attended a meeting held by Volney in the community last week to discuss the lack of employment in the area. It was at this meeting that Volney told the residents he had tried in the past to secure jobs for them with CEPEP but had been thwarted by certain councillors. Most residents said they, too, felt they were being used by some councillors as pawns in a political war, but they also admitted they were simply not qualified for any other types of jobs. Most residents were willing to speak but refused to give their names, for fear of being left out of any future work programmes. There were other issues they felt Volney could have solved by now, they said. \"The drains in the area real bad,\" said one resident. \"It have dengue in this village affecting our children.\" Another single mother said she has for months begged the San Juan/ Laventille Regional Corporation and the office of her MP to trim the trees around her modest home. \"It could fall on me and my children any time, and he not taking me on,\" she said. In St Joseph, Volney had more support. A number of people said they felt their MP \"was trying\", but they felt \"PNM elements\" within the area and in the local government councils were trying to make him look bad. \"They didn't take it nice when they lose,\" one man said. \"They making sure he hands tied now, so he will look like he not doing anything and don't care about the people.\" Retiree Leon Legall, 72, agreed and said Volney was \"one man trying to change a culture of laziness\". \"A lot of people here don't want to work, but they want money,\" he said. \"Don't take them on. I believe Mr Volney is trying his best, but he can only do so much. I also appreciate that he seems to speak his mind. He doesn't mix matters and says what he has to say without fear, whether it is outside here or in the Parliament.\" Still, there were detractors. One man, who did not want to be identified as he is employed with a State entity, said Volney has turned a deaf ear to them. The man claimed he and others have complained that the St Joseph Police Station has created congestion on Market Street by filling it with wrecked cars and vehicles that were involved in accidents. \"We tired complain about this, and Mr Volney has taken no action,\" the man said. \"Also, the Medical Associates Private Hospital has more or less taken away the public park from us in a number of ways. First, the children cannot play there because they say it is too noisy for their patients. So taxpayers are paying to upkeep a park that is of no use to the community. Then they burn their medical waste any time of day or night, and this makes some people nauseous. They also allow some of their wastewater to run through the main drains, and this is wrong.\" The man said some residents have also asked Volney to spruce up the main recreation grounds and add infrastructure to make it more user-friendly. \"We get nothing so far,\" he said. \"And where are the vocational courses for the youths We have a community centre that can be used for them to have classes. We need employment in this area, but the youths need help to get qualified. If Mr Volney is not careful, he will never win back a seat here again.\" See Page 20 for a response from MP Carolyn Seepersad-Bachan, following the March 18 \"MP Monitor\" story on her performance in the San Fernando West constituency.\"I'M doing my best,\" Minister of Justice and St Joseph MP Herbert Volney has said of his constituents' complaints. Volney said yesterday there were areas within his constituency which were \"not easy to manage\", and among them, the traditionally troubled squatting community of Bangladesh. \"The expectations of the people in this community are very high,\" Volney said. \"Their problems have been ongoing for years and have not been easy to resolve because most of them do not have the education.\" Getting a little tongue-in-cheek, Volney said: \"They want jobs that many of them do not have the education for. I will look for jobs for them in the Central Bank (of Trinidad and Tobago) and in the Office of the Prime Minister. If there are those who qualify, then they can have these jobs,\" he joked. \"Other than that, I will also look for sustainable jobs for them,\" he said. Volney said his office, for some time, has worked on relocating the community to a housing scheme, which he feels will help them to \"feel better and rise above Bangladesh as we know it\". Volney said since taking office, he has tried to furnish the community with employment from CEPEP but had no co-operation from some councillors. \"It has been a phenomenal disaster, and I have had to take over the seeking of the contracts myself,\" he said. \"So I hope this part of it will be resolved soon.\" Despite the claims of some constituents, he considers himself \"very and easily accessible\". \"There are three MP offices set up in my constituencythey are at Mt Lambert, St Joseph and Aranjuez,\" Volney said by phone. \"I see a lot of people through these offices, many of them from Bangladesh,\" he said. \"I have touched many people and helped many. I am trying my best.\" On the issues raised in St Joseph proper, Volney said he cannot help people if they do not make him aware of the problems. \"This is the first I am hearing of the Medical Associates issue,\" he said. \"If this had come through my office, I am certain we would have looked into it, but now that it has been brought to my attention, certainly, I will.\" The parking along Market Street of wrecked cars and vehicles that have been involved in accidents has been going on for over a year, Volney said, and he has spent almost as much time trying to change it. \"Yes, I am very aware of that problem,\" he said. \"I have written to the Commissioner of Police (Dwayne Gibbs) and the Deputy Commissioner (Jack Ewatski) on this. My requests to have the cars removed and the practice stopped have been ignored. \"This is one of the reasons I have turned completely against the Commissioner and the Deputy Commissioner. I am of the opinion that they need to pack up and leave our country because they cannot deliver, even on simple matters.\" Volney was thankful, however, for his supporters. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/top-international-business-story-in-europe-s-financial-crisis/article_0e50b4dc-076c-577a-9e14-ec4a7953ae73.html", "TITLE": " Top international business story in 2011: Europe's financial crisis ", "DATE": "Dec 26, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "A memorial is shown outside of an Apple store in Palo Alto, California, on October 11. Steve Jobs, the Apple founder and former CEO who invented and masterfully marketed ever-sleeker gadgets that transformed everyday technology, from the personal computer to the iPod and iPhone, died on October 10, 2011. A memorial is shown outside of an Apple store in Palo Alto, California, on October 11. Steve Jobs, the Apple founder and former CEO who invented and masterfully marketed ever-sleeker gadgets that transformed everyday technology, from the personal computer to the iPod and iPhone, died on October 10, 2011. Europe took the financial world on a stomach-churning ride in 2011. The rising threat of default by heavily indebted European countries spread fear across financial markets and weighed on economies worldwide. As the year came to a close, banks and investors nervously watched Europe's political and financial leaders scramble to prevent the 17-nation eurozone from breaking apart. Several of the other biggest business stories of the year highlighted the global economy's linkages: A British phone-hacking scandal shook the foundations of Rupert Murdoch's U.S.-based media empire; a nuclear disaster in Japan stymied auto plants in the US and beyond; and the price of gasoline surged because of unrest in the Middle East and growing demand in Asia and Latin America. In the US, political squabbling led to the first credit downgrade for government debt, the economy suffered its fourth straight disappointing year and Apple founder Steve Jobs died. The European financial crisis was chosen as the top business story of the year by business editors at The Associated Press. The sluggish U.S. economy came in second, followed by the death of Jobs. 1. EUROPEAN FINANCIAL CRISIS. The government-debt crunch rattled Europe's financial system and weighed on the global economy. Portugal became the third European country, after Greece and Ireland the year before, to require a bailout as its borrowing costs soared. And investors grew worried that countries with much larger debts, such as Spain and Italy, would also need help. Financial markets were volatile all year as hopes rose and then were dashed that forceful steps would be taken to prevent the financial crisis from becoming Europe's version of the 2008 collapse of Lehman Brothers, which triggered a global financial panic and deepened the Great Recession. Banks worried that they or their partners wouldn't be able to cover losses if governments defaulted, so they cut back on lending. European governments, facing ever higher borrowing costs, reined in spending a policy response that is expected to stunt much-needed economic growth. Analysts estimate the slowdown in Europe, America's number one trading partner, will cut US economic growth next year. 2. BAD US ECONOMY: YEAR FOUR. The Great Recession may have ended, but the economic recovery continued to disappoint. For the first six months of the year, the economy grew at an annual rate of just 0.9 per cent. Growth improved to a two per cent rate in the third quarter and a three per cent growth rate is forecast for the fourth quarter. Still, 2 years after economists say the recession ended, 25 million people remain unemployed or unable to find full-time work. The unemployment rate fell from nine per cent in October to 8.6 per cent in November, providing a hopeful sign. Yet the housing market remained burdened by foreclosures and falling prices in many metropolitan areas. How to fix the economy became the top campaign issue for Republican presidential contenders. 3. STEVE JOBS DIES. The college dropout who helped popularise the personal computer and created the iPod, iPhone and iPad, died on October 5. That was two months after Apple Inc., which Jobs started in a Silicon Valley garage in 1976, briefly surpassed Exxon Mobil Corp. as the most valuable publicly traded company in the world. Jobs cultivated a countercultural sensibility and a minimalist design ethic. He rolled out one sensational product after another, even during the recession and as his health was failing. He first helped change computers from a geeky hobbyist's obsession to a necessity of modern life. In recent years, he upended the music business with the iPod and iTunes, transformed the smart phone market with the iPhone and created the tablet market with the iPad. 4. THE US CREDIT DOWNGRADE. The inability of political leaders to come up with a long-term plan to reduce the federal budget deficit led the credit rating agency Standard & Poor's to take away Uncle Sam's sterling AAA credit rating for the first time. The political bickering enraged voters, spooked investors and led to the lowest consumer confidence level of the year. But the nation's long-term borrowing costs fell after the crisis. The reason: US debt still looks safer to investors than almost everything else, especially European debt. 5. RUPERT MURDOCH AND THE HACKING SCANDAL. The man whose worldwide media empire thrives on covering scandal became the center of a dramatic one. A British tabloid newspaper owned by Murdoch's News Corp, which also owns Fox News and The Wall Street Journal, hacked the phone of a murdered schoolgirl. Murdoch was not charged with a crime, but an investigation by British authorities raised questions about Murdoch's ability to run his worldwide media empire. News Corp. fired several executives and closed the newspaper at the center of the scandal, the News of the World. 6. JAPAN EARTHQUAKE. An earthquake and tsunami that crippled the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear reactor, owned by Tokyo Electric Power Co., cut off supplies of crucial Japanese parts and idled factories thousands of miles away. Auto companies, especially Toyota and Honda, were hit hardest. Inventory of certain models, especially hybrids, fell short at dealerships, reducing sales and sending retail prices higher. The worst nuclear accident since Chernobyl led countries around the world to reconsider nuclear power. Germany decided to abandon nuclear by 2022. 7. GASOLINE PRICES HIT ANNUAL RECORD.: The retail price of gasoline averaged US$3.53 per gallon for the year, eclipsing the 2008 record of US$3.24 per gallon. Americans drove less and switched to more fuel efficient cars, but it wasn't enough to offset the higher prices. A bigger percentage of household income went into the gas tank in 2011 than any year since 1981. Economists say the high prices shaved half a percentage point off US economic growth. 8. SOCIAL MEDIA IPOs TAKE OFF. Shares of the business social networking site LinkedIn more than doubled when it went public in May, recalling the froth of the dot-com boom. LinkedIn was followed by large IPOs from online radio company Pandora Media, online discount site Groupon and social gaming site Zynga. But the market is treacherous: shares of Pandora, Groupon and Zynga all traded below their offering prices soon after they were listed. Market anticipation is high for a Facebook IPO in 2012. 9. OCCUPY WALL STREET. On September 17, several hundred protesters gathered at a small plaza about a block from the New York Stock Exchange. They slept in tents, ate donated meals and protested income inequality and the influence of money in politics. The movement inspired protesters around the world who camped in city centers and business hubs to complain about unemployment, CEO pay and a decline in upward social mobility. 10. THE DOWNFALL OF MF GLOBAL AND JON CORZINE. The former governor, senator and co-chairman of Goldman Sachs lost control of a small brokerage firm he agreed to run in 2010. Saddled with huge debt and risky bets on European bonds, MF Global was forced to file for bankruptcy protection on Halloween after trading partners and investors got spooked. It was soon discovered that $1.2 billion in customer money was missing. Corzine told Congress he had no idea where the money went. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/when-doing-nothing-is-not-an-option/article_95ac69ea-1d73-5ed5-a1c6-700e72c5bc6b.html", "TITLE": " When doing nothing is not an option ", "DATE": "May 2, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "On a fateful December day when Christmas shopping occupied the minds of most people, a 16-inch diameter sea line broke at the State-owned refinery, sending a rush of black fuel oil into the Gulf of Paria and along the south western coastline. The effect of that spill is still being felt today by fisherfolk and people in poor coastal communities. The Sunday Express takes a close look at the chain of events that led to this country's worst environmental disaster. This is the eighth in a series of articles by Camini Marajh, Head, Express Investigative Desk State oil and gas giant Petrotrin broke the law, aided and abetted by the state regulatory agencies tasked with the job of protecting life and the environment. State regulators, including the Ministry of Energy and Energy Resources (MEEA) turned a blind eye to repeated safety violations in the thousands by the state-owned company which has shown a cavalier disregard for safety, the environment and the truth. The oil and gas giant, which is critical to the financial well being of the country was given a free pass by all of the State watchdog agencies and was left \u2014 for the most part \u2014 to its own devices to do as it pleased and take care of serious safety hazards as it saw fit or as in the case of No.10 sea line \u2014 not at all. Continuing Sunday Express investigations show that the MEEA dropped the ball and allowed a major state operator to simply roll-over the annual laundry list of issued warnings with no consequence to how it does business or threat of shut down. No investigation about who inside Petrotrin made the call to skip crucial inspections or keep a weakened and severely corroded 16-inch sea line in continued and dangerous service. Petrotrin's free pass The line Minister and Government's chief regulator, Kevin Ramnarine showed no stomach for going after the rogue State operator which he acknowledged has consistently failed to act with dispatch on issued warnings in the thousands from the Ministry's Inspection Unit or Health, Safety, Security, Environmental/Measurement Division (HSSE/M). The man who is supposed to safeguard the wider national interest and ensure energy operators scrupulously follow industry best practices and comply with the law breached a duty of care by holding the State-owned oil and gas giant to a less stringent standard. In prepared remarks to a series of questions from Independent Senator David Small on April 2, Ramnarine admitted to Petrotrin's continued failure to tackle health and safety maintenance issues. \"The ministry conducts an annual inspection of Petrotrin's oil producing and storage facilities, and there have been instances where these facilities have not adhered to all environmental, health and safety practices as required by the MEEA,\" he told the Senate, adding: \"Where facilities have not adhered to these standards, a notice of deficiency is issued and the company is required to take corrective action.\" Getting away with repeated failures He read three years figures into the Hansard record, seemingly unperturbed by the high number of notifications which were in the thousands or the high rate and annual roll-over of unresolved safety issues in an already dangerous work environment which has claimed ten lives in the last decade. Ramnarine, who has refused to respond directly to this reporter's requests for answers to questions about the spill or related safety and oversight issues, on the specific Small question of whether the MEEA has considered \"sitting with Petrotrin to come up with a plan\" to take care of outstanding \"deficiencies\", said: \"That is exactly what the National Facilities Audit will accomplish. We have, of course to recognise that Petrotrin, though a company which is now 21 years old, sits on inherited assets that are, in some cases, close to 100 years old.\" He talked about the environmental mess left behind by the multinational energy corporations as though that was an excuse for Petrotrin's rogue conduct and continued failure to adequately appreciate risk and implement basic measures to protect the lives of its 5,000 workers and the environment. It has been the scripted response so far of company officials to why Petrotrin failed to follow the maintenance advice of its own experts. \"Petrotrin has inherited the assets and liabilities, including aged plant and infrastructure, of several predecessor companies. We continue to refurbish and upgrade as quickly and as economically as resources would allow. Regular and preventive maintenance are key aspects of our operations,\" Petrotrin president Khalid Hassanali said, in an e-mail response. As reported previously in this series, the company's former head, inspection engineering, Gamini Hapuarachchi had developed a ten-year integrity management plan to overhaul aged marine assets identified on Petrontrin's Risk Assessment Matrix (RAM) as potentially dangerous and high risk. No 10 sea line was one of six identified high risk pipelines which missed two crucial scheduled inspections in 2010 and 2011. Coy with spill details Minister Ramnarine, who had early knowledge on December 17 of the Petrotrin oil spill and played coy with the details as the country worried about mystery leaks and the threat of unknown saboteurs, hedged his bets on the question of possible Government sanctions against the Lindsay Gillette-chaired board of directors and Hassanali-led executive management. \"That is a matter that could be considered for a future question,\" he advised the Senator, perhaps mindful of the several outstanding probes, increased public scrutiny and call for scalps by union boss Ancel Roget, who has been sharply critical of his and the company's handling of the oil spill. The minister talked about his Government's plan to launch a national facilities audit of the energy sector as a cure-all for Petrotrin's failure to take reasonable actions to eliminate identified safety hazards. He gave no account about what he has done to bring the renegade State-owned-and-managed energy giant to account since the disastrous events of December 17 or whether it is business as usual at the Pointe-a-Pierre refinery. Ramnarine, who went to Petrotrin's defence in the immediate aftermath of the oil spill and read from the same company cue cards, told the Senate on April 2 that: \"The ministry and, by extension, of course, the Cabinet has been very proactive. The Cabinet two weeks ago approved the plan for the national facilities audit of the energy sector, whereby the MEEA conducts safety and operations audits, on a periodic basis.\" The Government's big fix According to Minister Ramnarine: \"The national facilities audit is aimed at looking at the entire sector, not only Petrotrin but the east coast and Point Lisas and Point Fortin and so on, and I think, therefore, that is one policy position that we have taken post this oil spill that we really are ramping up the level of audit work being undertaken by the MEEA, as had been done by BP, as you know, over the last three years on their own facilities.\" (Post the Gulf of Mexico oil spill). He did not say who exactly would do this country-wide audit given the severe staffing shortage at the ministry's inspection unit or why Petrotrin is not being held to account for failing to follow its own integrity management plan or issued safety warnings from the State's regulatory agencies. Also, why there has been no consequence to Petrotrin's negligent conduct that led to the spill. No word either as to why he has not used his authority as the State's regulator-in-chief to issue a stop order to the energy giant responsible for the December oil spill. His response to the long laundry list of safety lapses and dangerous operating procedures by a State corporation that has repeatedly been caught lying has been muted as has his People's Partnership Government. Operating outside the law If Minister Ramnarine is at all worried that the State oil and gas company is operating recklessly and dangerously outside this country's HSE laws, he has not communicated that to the national community nor has he done anything about bringing Petrotrin to book over the thousands of safety warnings issued to the company. He has remained publicly silent on the issue. Weak State oversight and a severely understaffed and underpaid Inspection Unit in the MEEA were contributing factors that led to the environmental disaster, according to persons familiar with the situation. The inspection unit is the State's main agency overseeing the energy sector throughout the country and was so behind its workload it completely missed Petrotrin's marine facility when No.10 sea line dramatically burst open. The marine facility is a critical part of Petrotrin's daily operations and comprises a network of high pressure pipelines that are used to move crude and other hazardous product into and out of the Pointe-a-Pierre plant. Sources with knowledge of the situation say the refinery's marine facility literally slipped through the inspection cracks with no inspection audit conducted at the facility in five or more years. The unit is supposed to do annual inspections of all of the country's energy installations in both the State and private sectors. Persons with knowledge of the situation say the unit has been starved for critical resources and is currently operating with just 40 inspectors for all of the upstream and downstream industries, in all of Trinidad and Tobago, including rigs, seismic survey vessels, onshore terminals, offshore platforms, well sites, LNG terminals, bunkering warehouse facilities, petrochemical plants, road-tank wagons, transmission distribution pipelines and the whole spectrum of industrialised plants \u2014 from methanol and ammonia to nitrogen and hydrogen (both state and private). Cultural failure Poor pay and an understaffed department struggling to keep up with the huge task of country-wide inspections led to vast regulatory gaps in the system, Sunday Express investigations have found. The network of distribution pipelines were among identified energy assets that had not been inspected by the MEEA when No.10 ruptured last December, sending over 7,000 barrels of bunker fuel oil into the Gulf of Paria. But even if the department had somehow managed to conduct the scheduled inspection with its limited manpower, the question remains about whether Petrotrin would have heeded the warning given the fact it knew the enormous risks it was taking by continuing to use lines identified as potentially dangerous and high risk by its own technical experts. The evidence so far shows a company that took calculated and dangerous risks given the known condition of No.10 sea line (recommended for change-out since 1996) and failed to follow its own integrity management (Hapuarachchi) plan, industry standards or warnings that the line was extremely corroded and would rupture if not upgraded. \"It was not a question of if it would rupture but when,\" said a Petrotrin source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Industry experts and former and current Petrotrin officials have painted a scathing picture of cultural failure at Petrotrin, citing poor management, lack of sufficiently trained technical professionals, failure to comply with industry codes, political interference and a company that puts profits before safety. Nobody minding the store Successive administrations have milked the State oil and gas company for all they could get, more interested in the billion-dollar deals and costly plant upgrades than on ensuring that the company operates safely and takes care of aged, badly maintained and vulnerable infrastructure critical to its business. The situation is further exacerbated by the failure of supposedly independent State regulatory agencies like the Environmental Management Authority (EMA) and the Occupational Health and Safety Agency (OSHA) to hold Petrotrin to account. Persons with knowledge of the situation say the December spill could have been prevented with better oversight. One HSE energy sector expert said the inspections don't go far enough. Perhaps most troubling, is the lack of prosecutions brought against the State oil and gas company by the country's two main oversight authorities. And it is not because of a lack of hard evidence. As reported in this series, Petrotrin's own inspection reports and other internal company documents have catalogued a long list of serious health and safety hazards that pose a threat to life and the environment. The evidence on record suggests that both State agencies have been less than rigorous in ensuring that Petrotrin stays safe. Worst yet, they rely in the main on voluntary compliance. Petrotrin's own data suggests that all of the State's oversight agencies \u2014 including the State's regulator-in-chief and line minister \u2014 failed to do their jobs. There has been no flood of penalties, no increased enforcement for safety lapses, no prosecutions for the near misses or accidents that have claimed lives or devastated coastal communities and ecosystems as far as 28 kilometres away from the spill site and no State directive to shut down the State energy giant until identified high risk safety hazards are fixed. Petrotrin untouchable Industry experts question the State's apparent reluctance to go after one of its own. A veteran oilman, who spoke on background, said the serious safety shortfalls highlighted in this series should have led to increased regulatory scrutiny of Petrotrin which has a worse health, environment and safety record than most. As reported previously, Petrotrin's failure to adopt a find-it and fix-it strategy following the December oil spill has led to six more oil and gas leaks (that we know of) for this year already. Experts inside and outside of Petrotrin say the company has systemic safety and health problems. They pointed to the company's poor safety culture where the main worry is \"how much\" a problem will cost to fix as opposed to \"how soon it could be fixed\". There has been a spate of serious safety incidents over the last decade and just as many deaths which raise questions about how Petrotrin was able to get away with breaking the rules for so long and why the state's oversight agencies failed to do comprehensive inspections of a known offender There are questions too about why the oversight agencies failed to rein in the culture of risk and breakdown maintenance that prevails at the State energy giant. Also, how did they miss the badly maintained and clamped No.10 with its worn hangers, weakened pipeline, leaking expansion joints and high-priority diagnostic Conflict of interest Perhaps the answer lies in the interconnected relationships between the central figures and the State's reliance on the Petrotrin money machine. Shyam Dyal, head, HSE Corporate at Petrotrin was deputy chair of the EMA up until a year ago. The Kamla Persad-Bissessar administration put an executive from an oil and gas company that is arguably the largest potential polluter (by nature of its operations) as deputy chair of the environmental watchdog agency. As to whether potential threats to the environment and the network of badly-maintained and leaking pipelines were overlooked as a result of this conflict of interest Chairman of the EMA, Dr Allan Bachan says no. But according to him, the EMA relies on Petrotrin to do its own voluntary monitoring and to provide reports of non-compliance to the State regulatory agency. In a short phone interview, the EMA chairman insisted that the agency's authority extends only to CEC (Certificate of Environmental Clearance) approved infrastructure and not petrochemical plants 100 years old. He claimed archaic legislation and understaffing as a defence for lax inspections at the State oil and gas giant. Dr Bachan refused to discuss the oil spill, saying only that the matter was still under investigation. Asked why the EMA failed to ensure that Petrotrin complied with the law, he again pointed to deficient legislation. But Section 16 (1) of the act gives the authority \"general functions\" to take appropriate action \"for the prevention and control of pollution and conservation of the environment\". Lack of enforcement The authority also has wide powers under Sections 47, 52, 58, 59, 60, 61 and 62 to do \"all things necessary\" to protect the environment. It also has the power to go after Petrotrin for criminal negligence under Section 70 of the act but according to Dr Bachan that is a difficult hurdle because: \"You have to prove it.\" Section 70 (1) states in part: \"Any person who through the release or handling of any pollutant or hazardous substance, knowingly or recklessly endangers human life or health, commits an offence.\" The EMA's position, according Bachan, is to allow the Government appointed task force of which he is chair to do its job. He did not say if the committee's remit extends to examining the EMA's role as a failed regulator. He declined further comment. Petrotrin was ordered to pay $20 million in fines related to its poor response to the spill 18 days after the incident. The identified breaches, however, had nothing to do with cause or the company's reckless and negligent conduct to take decisive steps to prevent the oil spill. The OSH agency which is mandated by law to ensure that employers provide a safe workplace did little more than the Inspection Unit of the MEEA. It simply wrote up a bunch of enforcement notices. The Agency, which has wide powers to enter a workplace without the benefit of a warrant, in an e-mailed response to a question about the slew of potential dangerous hazards identified in Petrotrin's inspection reports, said: \"Industrial establishments are targeted for compliance and enforcement activities by the OSH Agency based on risk profiling, risk rating and other criteria which include factors such as compliance history and accident frequency rate. Throughout the years several plants in the refinery have been targeted and compliance and enforcement programmes implemented by inspectors of the OSH Agency. Some of these compliance programmes were conducted jointly with officials of the MEEA, with reports of the findings being submitted to Petrotrin.\" State complicity Asked if the agency was aware of Petrotrin's pipe infrastructure problems and whether it did anything to ensure compliance to industry safety standards, the agency said: \"This question is vague and therefore does not lend itself to an informed response. However, assuming that reference is being made to the recent oil spill at Pointe-a-Pierre please be advised that this is an active investigation, and as a consequence we prefer to reserve comment, so as not to prejudice the process. We can confirm though that the situation has engaged the attention of the OSH Agency.\" What the agency neglected to say was that its attention was engaged only after the No.10 sea line failure. The agency which can make a demand for the production of company records and other data failed to respond to a question about how many accidents and fatalities were caused by some of the hazards identified in Petrotrin's own data over the last decade. What has emerged so far suggests that the EMA, the OSH Agency, the Inspection Unit of the MEEA and the Government regulator-in-chief, Kevin Ramnarine each played a part in protecting Petrotrin from the legal consequences of its negligent conduct. In the wake of the oil spill disaster, they have a duty to now tell the country why the rules do not apply to Petrotrin. Continues tomorrow Oil spill facts Date of Incident: December 17, 2013 Source: No.10 sea line Actual number of barrels of bunker fuel oil spilled -7,554 (source: Energy Minister Kevin Ramnarine). Oil recovered: 4,343 barrels Coastline affected: 10.5 miles of beach along the south western peninsula Wetlands affected: two hectares or 4.9 acres in Rousillac Total volume of spill dispersant Coreexit 9500A used: 31 drums or 1,705 gallons (source: Energy Minister Kevin Ramnarine). Hardest hit community: La Brea \u2014 population of about 3,080 consisting of 979 households (source: 2000 CSO population data). The data indicate an estimated 53 per cent unemployment rate in La Brea and its immediate environs. Fishing and farming is reported to be the main source of employment in the area. Primary responder: The responsible party for the spill, Petrotrin. Current spill tab: About $57 million including $20 million EMA fine Safety warnings issued to Petrotrin by the MEEA's Inspection Unit: 2010 roll-overs: 966. 2011 \u2014 2,085. Number rectified in 2011 \u2014 1,193. 2011 roll-overs: 1,858. New warnings issued in 2012 - 1,326. Number fixed \u2014 1,435. Roll-overs into 2013 \u2014 1,785. New warnings issued last year - 1,923. No figures were available for the number of problems resolved. The big spill: Not a chance occurrence but a culmination of negligent events. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/good-start-some-missteps/article_22646077-26e6-5938-854b-428539ac9a96.html", "TITLE": " Good start, some missteps ", "DATE": "Jun 30, 2010 ", "CONTENT": " THE People's Partnership will hardly enjoy a honeymoon period in government. Because its predecessors were so delinquent in addressing real problems affecting citizens, the people are crying out for relief from the ills that affect them. Many voted for the People's Partnership out of sheer frustration over the way ex-prime minister Manning and his key ministers treated their concerns with contempt. Maybe their expectations are unrealistic. No government can reduce the levels of crime we have experienced over the past decade in a few months. I do not envy National Security Minister, Brigadier John Sandy, as he grapples with robberies and burglaries that have reached epidemic proportions, and murders that continue unabated. Sandy does have a major advantage over Martin Joseph: he has been in the trenches, having served in the Defence Force in varying capacities, from a private soldier to Chief of Defence Staff (CDS). He therefore understands the strengths and weaknesses of Defence Force personnel, and by virtue of his interaction with other arms of the Protective Services, he would understand their challenges too. I note that already he has indicated his intention to legitimise the SAUTT, a grossly-maligned unit that another of his military colleagues, Brigadier Peter Joseph, has built over the past five years or so. My understanding is that SAUTT is confined to gathering intelligence (information on criminals and their activities). In spite of the fact that its members are trained as an elite fighting unit, it does not have the power to act on the information it gathers. In other words, SAUTT is bogged down by bureaucracy. The UNC in opposition was very critical of it, saying it cost a lot but did little. Now they have the power to rectify this anomaly. That should bring greater firepower to bear on those who believe their right to terrorise entire communities comes from the barrel of a gun. There are many other measures that must be implemented if the Government hopes to reduce crime, first to manageable levels, and ultimately to insignificance. An overwhelming majority of the population are law-abiding citizens. Given the necessary assurances, they can play a pivotal role in reducing crime. A people's partnership must mean more than ministers and senators in government: it must signal a new era in which government partners with the people to address national problems. Meanwhile, Works Minister Jack Warner has tackled head-on some problems plaguing his ministry in a way only Jack does. He rolled up his sleeves, found himself in Caparo where residents faced a crisis caused by irresponsible sand-mining practices. Within 48 hours he got Energy Minister Carolyn Seepersad-Bachan to halt sand-mining in that general area. It's not that the new government is against quarryingI should hope not. It's simply that too many quarry operators have been a law unto themselves, they have ignored environmental concerns, damaged rural roads, made living hell for nearby residents, and they got away with it. This cannot be allowed to continue. The PNM Government talked about it, but never acted. Jack showed up Colm Imbert for what he isn't, and that in short orderno pun intended. Jack's other initiative, a declaration to move the main operations of the Licensing Department to Central Trinidad, is most welcome. Decentralisation of ministries and critical state agencies has been touted for 30, 40 years, but without any affirmative action. Since our current network of roads and highways makes no part of the country difficult to access (a PNM boast), shifting operations of agencies like Licensing would make life easier for both employees and the public. I hope the minister acts on this with dispatch. I must, however, warn Mr Warner (sounds good, eh) that his proposal to open up the Priority Bus Route (PBR) to the public is a disaster-in-the-making. I understand the urgency with which he wants to alleviate the horrendous traffic jams motorists face on a daily basis trying to access Port of Spain. But opening up the PBR to the public, even for limited periods and with pre-conditions, is a recipe for chaos. If anything, the PBR needs to shed some of its current traffic-load. I know what I write about since I use the PTSC bus service to travel from Chaguanas to POS during weekdays. Already there are too many vehicles on that special road. But in off-peak periods, the bus takes around half-hour to make the trip. With additional traffic on the PBR, commute-time will increase by 15 to 30 minutes. Knowing Trinis as we do, every-man-Jack would rush to the PBR to \"try out\" the new system. That will add yet another clogged artery to the city and it would defeat the purpose of the dedicated bus (and maxi-taxis) road. Because the PBR is a narrow, two-lane road that criss-crosses around 30 traffic lights/intersections, accidents will increase exponentially. Also, how many policemen would be required to ensure the proposed usage-rules are enforced I urge the minister to consult with traffic engineers and planners before executing any such plan. They may well advise that he not only leave the PBR as is, but he start construction of another dedicated bus and public transport road from Chaguanas to Mt Hope. That's one solution to North-South traffic woes. Implementing it would also signal the timely death of Imbert's $15 billion bound-to-fail rapid rail. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/awaiting-cal-s-report/article_33fa94a3-a973-525a-8947-27182afedc35.html", "TITLE": " Awaiting CAL's report ", "DATE": "Jul 31, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "There is usually a smattering of applause when a Caribbean Airlines (CAL) flight touches a runway anywhere in the world. BW 523's runway mishap in Guyana will now increase the volume on CAL's flights, part gratitude part relief. Aviation incidents are usually related to human or mechanical issues or physical conditions: sometimes all three. This one will be figured out and ascribed a cause or series of causes. Even before that we learn a few things. CAL is not infallible and has a first major accident. Much can happen even after an aircraft safely touches down, so when you do applaud, stay buckled-in and keep in mind the job is not finished. We also know that Guyana is a lucrative market for CAL and not all airports are created equal. CAL needs some assurances in Guyana. It has to take stock of consistency in passenger and aircraft safety and emergency response. The initial sounds out of Guyana point to matters for concern and that is where the Prime Minister and Guyana's President will take the lead. With all of what has landed on the plates of the PM, Transport Minister and CAL's board it is funny enough that out of this incident CAL's beleaguered board may actually have found a unifying force, leading right up to the PM. The PM's visit to the crash site in Guyana is one of those damned if you do, damned if you don't things. I could not appreciate the reason for the trip at a time when the PM herself could do very little. The situation required technical and tactical responses and a political jaunt was not one of them. But later on I conceded that the trip was important in demonstrating both the level of oversight Trinidad intends to provide to the incident and the forward plan. It also demonstrates the PM's acceptance of responsibility: it is not just a CAL issue but a larger Guyana and TT issue. Guyana and Guyanese around the world are important to CAL. On most of those CAL flights out of Toronto and JFK Trinidadians are a minority and over the four seasons Guyanese and Guyana bound travellers are dominant CAL flyers. In fact on my CAL flight last May I was struck by the high level of Guyanese corporate advertising in CAL's fabulous Caribbean Beat in-flight magazine, a sign of Guyana's significance to the airline. This incident should have little impact on CAL's Guyana market as it currently lacks competition on the routes. But if the incident shows any sign initially of being related to physical or infrastructure issues in Guyana then CAL and the PM must act urgently. With the short- and long-term in mind, the involvement of both political leaders is welcome and the immediate focus has to be on the physical conditions BW 523 met that morning and the support given to the flight. The focus also has to be on Guyana's emergency response, though our current understanding is informed by anecdotes carried in the media. In Trinidad and Tobago then transport minister Jack Warner got caught in a national imbroglio in 2010 over runway lighting and contracts for it. At that time he emphasised the urgency, suggesting the country's international airports were very close to disaster given the inadequacy of lighting. It seemed at the time that we were winging it, since Warner pointed to deficiencies which had existed for a while and posed a persistent threat to aircraft and passenger safety. Could lighting or other infrastructure issues emerge as decisive or contributing factors in BW 523's runway mishap And if that is a factor, will we await a final report before we persuade Guyana to take action or will we act right away Sure enough Trinidad and Tobago may have taken its chances but assuming that lighting is or could be a factor, then Guyana was not as lucky. An aircraft snapped in two is no near miss. Could it also have been other infrastructure issues in Guyana Again we can await a full report or we can consider some of the passenger and crew anecdotes, the most critical of which will come from the persons piloting BW 523. There should also be a review of Trinidad and Tobago and all CAL's routes. We know that there were lighting issues at Piarco and Crown Point, but was that all of it The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA), the Airports Authority of Trinidad and Tobago (AATT) and CAL will have to tell us what other risks passengers and aircraft may face at our local airports and elsewhere as CAL continues on this perennial hustle to even out the bottom line. And even with all the sensitivities, would human factors feature in this investigation into BW 523 A day's-old report into the June 2009 crash of Airbus Flight 447 is instructive. A Daily Mail, UK report says that the report emphasises that \"as their Airbus A330 rolled from side to side in a tropical thunderstorm, pilots 32-year-old Pierre-Cedric Bonin and David Robert, 37, were unable to bring it under control''. And \"even when Marc Dubois, the 58-year-old captain of the plane, returned from a rest break, his deputies were panicking too much to even tell him what the problem was.'' CAL has excellent staff and crew which must have contributed to the airline's safety record. Nothing suggests human error in this incident but a final report would surely consider how crew can better handle physical, infrastructure or mechanical challenges given the potential benefit of hindsight. Depending on who is saying it various descriptors will be assigned to BW 523's split into two. The spin doctors are already at work and \"crash'' is already a runway mishap: alternatively \"incident'', \"accident'', \"issue'', \"problem'', \"challenge''. It is what it is and that is a reminder of fallibility and vulnerability in the face of which BW 523's captain, crew and passengers have earned applause. Not just a smattering. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/company-chiefs-favoured-sabotage-theory/article_a210a182-9a66-587a-b171-4f35069edc2a.html", "TITLE": " Company chiefs favoured sabotage theory ", "DATE": "Apr 14, 2014 ", "CONTENT": " On a fateful December day when Christmas shopping occupied the minds of most people, a 16-inch diameter sea line broke at the State-owned refinery, sending a rush of black fuel oil into the Gulf of Paria and along the south-western coastline. The effect of that spill is still being felt today by fisherfolk and people in poor coastal communities. The Express takes a close look at the chain of events that led to this country's worst environmental disaster in history. This is the sixth in a series of articles by Camini Marajh, head, Express Investigative Desk. Petrotrin's top brass, Lindsay Gillette and Khalid Hassanali, stayed on script over their handling of the December oil spill disaster even as they faced questions on key points about the company-issued version of events. Chairman Gillette, himself a former minister of energy in the Panday administration, defiantly maintained that unknown saboteurs were involved. Asked if he had any proof of this, Gillette, in an e-mail response to this reporter on March 21, said: \"Yes. The evidence that was available has been shared with the police and investigations are ongoing.\" As to what exactly that evidence might be, the chairman of the State oil and gas giant, who was an early proponent of the sabotage conspiracy, said only: \"I would prefer not to comment further.\" Hassanali, whose term as president of Petrotrin was extended for an additional two years 47 days before No 10 sea line dramatically ruptured, said: \"The number and chronology of the various incidents have been well reported previously and the company even took out full-page advertisements in the national media.\" Hassanali maintained that there were 11 spill incidents, including \"those of our business partners\", Trinity Exploration and Production Ltd and Neal and Massy Energy Resources Ltd. And, like his chairman, he hid behind the veil of an ongoing police probe to not disclose what evidence of sabotage the company has. \"The police was advised of all instances where sabotage was suspected and the relevant evidence was shared,\" he told the Express, noting that: \"For obvious reasons, we are unable to comment further on these matters.\" Petrotrin's top bosses and various Government officials, including line Minister Kevin Ramnarine had repeatedly asserted there was \"compelling evidence\" of sabotage in two of the 11 Petrotrin-reported spills, specifically Riser Platform No 5 and Rancho Quemado. Assistant Commissioner of Police Glen Hackett said yesterday the police are yet to come to any finding on the specific complaints of suspected sabotage. He confirmed that-south western division police have had several \"conversations\" with Petrotrin on the matter and that investigations are ongoing. He said: \"Given the national interest in the matter, we are moving with alacrity in the matter.\" However, as reported in last Sunday's Express, much of the company's so-called proof of sabotage just doesn't exist. The company's own investigation report into the RP No 5 incident made no such finding and put the blame squarely on a faulty rubber gasket. Much of the RP No 5 investigation report, including when the spill incident happened, contradicts the official version of events put out by Petrotrin and its top executives. Significantly, Petrotrin labelled the RP No 5 incident a \"deliberate act\" of sabotage before it had even appointed its team of company experts to investigate. The six-member team, headed by Dexter Hector, was appointed late in the day on December 23 and only began its investigations nearing year's end on December 27. The report itself was sharply critical of the lack of historical data, inspection reports and Management of Change (MOC) documents for repair work done on Riser Platform No 5, which forms part of Petrotrin's aged and poorly-maintained production and distribution infrastructure. The Hector probe also found that the accident investigation site on the eastern edge of the Soldado Main Field was not preserved in keeping with strict company guidelines and repairs to the busted rubber gasket were completed on December 19 before an investigation was even initiated. The report noted the team's inability to secure a \"list of physical evidence related to the blown gasket\", and the company's failure to keep a proper record of events, including the estimated start time of the spill. Company records report an alarm being raised by the captain of a marine vessel, C'est La Vie at about 12.30 p.m. on December 18, the day after the big 7,000-plus bunker fuel spill at the Pointe-a-Pierre refinery, which devastated miles of coastline and fishing communities along the south-western peninsula. The Hector Report found that, contrary to company claims, the response was slow and lacked critical booms and other spill-containment equipment. It also found that the company's first responders did not know what to do and apparently had no knowledge and/or training in oil spill response. It found that the company failed to follow industry standards for industrial pipe installation and maintenance. The gasket that blew was a wrong fit and breached several safety codes, according to the API (American Petroleum Institute) standard for offshore production platform piping systems, again contrary to Petrotrin's oft-repeated claims that it adhered to industry's best practices. The Hector probe estimated the size of the spill at about 40 barrels of crude oil and a leak time of about five hours, but conceded there were inconsistencies with the number of bags of Consorb or spill-absorbent material used. The report suggested that 50 bags of Consorb were used to contain the two Trinmar spills, specifically, RP No 5 and Platform 17. In the case of the latter spill, which was caused by a quarter-inch hole in a six-inch riser pipe, the estimated volume of the spill was said to be six barrels of crude oil. A leak time of three hours was given. Petrotrin insiders, however, spoke of an underreporting in the actual Trinmar spills. Persons with knowledge of the situation told the Express that about 1,000 bags of Consorb were used in addition to other marine assets to break up the spill. Hassanali has refuted reports that the executive management and board of directors of Petrotrin pushed the safety envelope by continuing to use old, corroded and leaky transmission pipelines to move hazardous product. \"Those allegations are not true,\" said Hassanali, stating that: \"The company has a robust Asset Integrity Management Programme, which exceeds statutory requirements. It includes planned maintenance schedules as well as preventive maintenance programmes based on periodic asset integrity and reliability inspections.\" This is at variance with the findings of this special Express investigation and Petrotrin's own inspections reports and other internal data. Both Hassanali and Gillette deny that the company operates on a system of breakdown maintenance. According to Hassanali: \"The company uses relevant and applicable codes and standards, including API and ASME, as well as industry best practices across its operations. Regular and scheduled maintenance is a key aspect of our operations.\" As reported in this series, several of the spill incidents, including sea line No 10, were caused by neglect of aged and under-maintained pipeline assets. On the question of serious competency issues at every level of the State company, including the board of directors and the executive management, chairman Gillette said this: \"There is a school of thought that says that the local energy industry suffers from what is referred to as 'the Oreo effect'\u2014a situation where you have a top layer of seasoned and experienced oil men, who have reached or are close to retirement age, a softer layer immediately beneath, which include persons not yet ready for leadership and who require further training and development in order to assume leadership, along with a third layer of young and bright persons but who lack industry experience.\" He admitted that, given the rapid growth in the industry and the attraction of high-paying jobs in the external energy industry, \"we have lost several of our best employees, so there may be some merit in that position.\" \u2014Continues on Sunday TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found.
